'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-04 20:22:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It seems to me that this would be a significantly easier feature to manage if the filtering was done on the basis of a role assigned to a tenant rather than directly on the tenant ids.   

That would allow information about tenants to be managed in keystone rather than Nova"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-04 20:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

To expand on my previous comment, one of the issues we find with things that are configured directly against a tenant in Nova (like quotas) is that there is no way for Nova to validate if the tenant_id is correct or not.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-05 09:43:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sorry, my additional comment took away my initial -1."}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-02-06 15:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Phil if I understand correctly what you are suggesting is to look into the user role in the tenant? If so how do you suggest to define this information in the aggregate?
The goal of the filter is to allow aggregates to run instances only from specific tenants independent of the user role. Is true that tenant_id metadata in the aggregate is not verified but as other filters it relies in the info provided by the admin.
Please can you clarify what you mean? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-02-07 15:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-02-07 21:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-07 23:06:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-nova-docs/14410 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-nova-pep8/19714 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-nova-python26/15858 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-nova-python27/15917 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/1538 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/1264 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/5578 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20565/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/7826 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-08 18:18:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Belmiro,

What I'm suggesting is that instead of making the aggregate metadata a list of tenant_ids (which are just foriegn keys to Nova) you make it a list or roles.

The role(s) of a tenant are defined in keystone and available in the context after authentication - so it should be just as easy to check on a tenant having the correct role as it is to check on the tenant itself.

The advantage of this is that it allows you to manage the rights of a tenant or set of tenants in keystone (where you manage other aspects of them), rather than in Nova

So for example in my model you would:
- Create a role in keystone for the aggregate (or use an existing role if appropriate)
- Associate that role with the aggregate in Nova via its metadata
- Assign the role in keystone to any tenants that you want to be able to use the aggregate

In effect its just changing one foreign keystone key (tenant_id) for another (role) - but it puts the association of privelieges to a tenant in keystone rather than in Nova.

You can't validated the foreign key in Nova, but in my apaproach the role can be descriptive and only has to be entered once.   Tenant IDs can be complex strings in a large system, and hence easy to get wrong when adding them to the aggregate. 

Cheers,
Phil"}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-02-08 21:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Phil,
thank you for the detailed explanation.
The implementation that you suggest is easy but in my opinion it changes the behavior of the filter.
My understanding is that a role is associated to a user inside a tenant. This means the filtering will be done per user role.
Inside a tenant, users can have different roles. So, it will be necessary to guarantee that all users inside a tenant have the "filter tenant role", because it will not be enough belong to a tenant.
 
cheers,
Belmiro'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-02-11 12:34:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

Hi Belmiro,

I take your point.   I would in general expect there to be only a few users to a tenant, and wouldn't personally see managing the role assignment as a big task, but your right in that it does shift the focus of the filter somewhat.

What's really missing here I think is the ability for Keystone to provide additional per-tenant data (i.e something beyond roles but still managed in keystone).

I'm still worried that on a large system managing the list of tenant id's in the metadata value will become painful, and you could quickly run into limits on the metadata value length.

However if this meets your use case then go ahead, and we can provide a different filter once we get better per-tenant data support from keystone"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-19 13:20:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think this looks very interesting, but the ramifications seem a little more than we want to race in the last day before g-3. I might suggest a havana design summit topic on multi-tenancy where this was an option."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-19 20:00:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-02-19 20:07:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM, this patch doesn't touch default behavior, has tests and documentation."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-19 20:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-27 17:04:10.000000000', 'message': 'Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates

A new scheduler filter that allows the creation of instances from
specific tenants in selected aggregates.
With this filter is possible to isolate tenants in a specific set
of compute nodes (aggregates).

If a host is in an aggregate that has the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can only create instances from that tenant(s).
A host can be in different aggregates.
If a host doesn't belong to an aggregate with the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can create instances from all tenants.

Implements: blueprint Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I119c809c54da9e9dc3ac506c02203d2d4422b06e
'}, {'created': '2013-01-27 19:48:22.000000000', 'message': 'Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates

commit_message:
Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates

A new scheduler filter that allows the creation of instances from
specific tenants in selected aggregates.
With this filter is possible to isolate tenants in a specific set
of compute nodes (aggregates).

If a host is in an aggregate that has the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can only create instances from that tenant(s).
A host can be in different aggregates.
If a host doesn't belong to an aggregate with the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can create instances from all tenants.

Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I119c809c54da9e9dc3ac506c02203d2d4422b06e

commit_message:
Handle lifecycle events in the compute manager

Update the compute manager to register an event handler
with the compute drivers. The initial handler will process
lifecycle event notifications, to allow prompt synchronization
of DB & hypervisor power states. This means that if a guest
admin does 'shutdown -h now' the libvirt driver in Nova will
immediately notice that and mark the guest as SHUTOFF rather
then leaving it RUNNING until the periodic task runs sometime
in the next 10 minutes

Blueprint: compute-driver-events
Change-Id: I39a6d450a6d6384b8be58aceea98e4395185cc38
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: Add support for lifecycle events in the libvirt driver

commit_message:
Add support for lifecycle events in the libvirt driver

This wires up the libvirt compute driver to process async
events from libvirtd and emit lifecycle events. This makes
use of the native libvirt event loop to handle I/O processing
which requires a native thread.

The native thread uses a queue + self-pipe to forward events
onto a green thread. The green thread reads events off the
queue and uses the emit_event method to dispatch them to the
compute manager.

Blueprint: compute-driver-events
Change-Id: Icd2cb7081adde10420ae55beebe60350afe21379
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-12 17:36:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add basic infrastructure for compute driver async events

This introduces the basic infrastructure to allow compute
drivers to emit asychronous events for processing by the
virt API. Initially the only event defined is a "lifecycle"
event which allows the virt API to immediately detect the
start and stop of virtual domain instances, without needing
to frequently poll the compute API.

The base compute driver gains some helper methods for queuing
and dispatch events. These helpers make use of python thread
lock to allow the compute driver impls to safely run event
handling in a native thread, separate from the eventlet
coroutines.

Blueprint: compute-driver-events

commit_message:
Add basic infrastructure for compute driver async events

This introduces the basic infrastructure to allow compute
drivers to emit asychronous events for processing by the
virt API. Initially the only event defined is a "lifecycle"
event which allows the virt API to immediately detect the
start and stop of virtual domain instances, without needing
to frequently poll the compute API.

The base compute driver gains a method enabling the manage
to register a callback to receive events, and another method
to allow driver subclasses to emit events.

Blueprint: compute-driver-events
Change-Id: Ic9abcd3f829c106e840538a01376862ab5b3485b
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-02-20 08:03:09.000000000', 'message': "Add deprecated_group Opt kwarg

We often wish to take existing configuration options and move them
from the DEFAULT group to a more specialized group, while still
supporting existing configurations.

We can support this by adding a new deprecated_group kwarg which
allows an option to be aliased to a name in another group e.g.

  CONF.register_opt(cfg.StrOpt('foo',
                               deprecated_name='bar',
                               deprecated_group='DEFAULT'),
                    group='blaa')

or where the option was simply moved between groups:

  CONF.register_opt(cfg.StrOpt('foo',
                               deprecated_group='DEFAULT'),
                    group='blaa')

Implements blueprint cfg-move-opts-between-groups

Change-Id: I4d974c71fab3e3c5c7a3e6514bdd9cb20e7200ff

commit_message:
Add deprecated_group Opt kwarg

We often wish to take existing configuration options and move them
from the DEFAULT group to a more specialized group, while still
supporting existing configurations.

We can support this by adding a new deprecated_group kwarg which
allows an option to be aliased to a name in another group e.g.

  CONF.register_opt(cfg.StrOpt('foo',
                               deprecated_name='bar',
                               deprecated_group='DEFAULT'),
                    group='blaa')

or where the option was simply moved between groups:

  CONF.register_opt(cfg.StrOpt('foo',
                               deprecated_group='DEFAULT'),
                    group='blaa')

Implements blueprint cfg-move-opts-between-groups

Change-Id: I4d974c71fab3e3c5c7a3e6514bdd9cb20e7200ff

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-20 07:55:17.000000000', 'message': 'plugin/nec: Make sure resources on OFC is globally unique.

Fixes bug 1127664

Network cannot be created in NEC plugin when OFC network ID is
unique inside a tenant. Some OFC implmenetations generate a network
ID unique inside a tenant. In this case generated network IDs on can
be duplicated in system-wide. To fix it, this changes resource ID on
OFC to REST URI to make sure IDs on OFC globally unique.

Fixes bug 1120962

Make sure NEC plugin creates shared networks

In Quantum resource relationship is not limited inside a tenant.
E.g., a non-owner tenant can create a port on a shared network.
To deal with it the provider layer should not be aware of tenants
each resource belongs to even when it has a kind of tenant concept.

This commit changes ofc_manager to pass a parent resource for resource
creation and identify a resouce by REST URI used to access OFC resources.
It decouples Quantum resource access model from OFC resource models.
OFC IDs created before this commit are also looked up.

Primary keys of OFC ID mapping tables are changed to quantum_id because
most of all accesses to these mapping tables are done by quantum_id.
However the current version of alembic does not support changing primary
keys, so new OFC ID mapping tables for tenant, network, port and packet
filter are created. Dropping the previous mapping tables will be done
along with the data migration logic.

This commit also changes the following minor issues.
- Make sure ID on ProgrammableFlow OpenFlow controller (PFC) is less than
  32 chars. The current PFC accepts only 31 chars max as ID and 127 chars
  as a description string.
- Some database accesses created their own session and did not support
  subtransactions. Make sure to use context.session passed from the API layer.
- Removes Unused methods (update_network, update_port) in trema/pfc drivers.

Change-Id: Ib4bb830e5f537c789974fa7b77f06eaeacb65333

commit_message:
plugin/nec: Make sure resources on OFC is globally unique.

Fixes bug 1127664

Network cannot be created in NEC plugin when OFC network ID is
unique inside a tenant. Some OFC implmenetations generate a network
ID unique inside a tenant. In this case generated network IDs on can
be duplicated in system-wide. To fix it, this changes resource ID on
OFC to REST URI to make sure IDs on OFC globally unique.

Fixes bug 1120962

Make sure NEC plugin creates shared networks

In Quantum resource relationship is not limited inside a tenant.
E.g., a non-owner tenant can create a port on a shared network.
To deal with it the provider layer should not be aware of tenants
each resource belongs to even when it has a kind of tenant concept.

This commit changes ofc_manager to pass a parent resource for resource
creation and identify a resouce by REST URI used to access OFC resources.
It decouples Quantum resource access model from OFC resource models.
OFC IDs created before this commit are also looked up.

Primary keys of OFC ID mapping tables are changed to quantum_id because
most of all accesses to these mapping tables are done by quantum_id.
However the current version of alembic does not support changing primary
keys, so new OFC ID mapping tables for tenant, network, port and packet
filter are created. Dropping the previous mapping tables will be done
along with the data migration logic.

This commit also changes the following minor issues.
- Make sure ID on ProgrammableFlow OpenFlow controller (PFC) is less than
  32 chars. The current PFC accepts only 31 chars max as ID and 127 chars
  as a description string.
- Some database accesses created their own session and did not support
  subtransactions. Make sure to use context.session passed from the API layer.
- Removes Unused methods (update_network, update_port) in trema/pfc drivers.

Change-Id: Ib4bb830e5f537c789974fa7b77f06eaeacb65333

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-20 07:55:10.000000000', 'message': 'Routing table configuration support on L3

Implements bp quantum-l3-routes

  -- Adding the extraroute extension
  -- Updating the routing table based on routes attribute on route
  -- Updated OVS plugin, linuxbridge plugin, metaplugin
     NEC plugin, Ryu plugin

  User can configure the routes through quantum client API by
  using the extension feature.
  sample
  quantum route-update <router_id> \
        --routes type=dict list=true destination=40.0.1.0/24,nexthop=10.1.0.10

Change-Id: I2a11486709e55d3143373858254febaabb93cfe8

commit_message:
Routing table configuration support on L3

Implements bp quantum-l3-routes

  -- Adding the extraroute extension
  -- Updating the routing table based on routes attribute on route
  -- Updated OVS plugin, linuxbridge plugin, metaplugin
     NEC plugin, Ryu plugin

  User can configure the routes through quantum client API by
  using the extension feature.
  sample
  quantum router-update <router_id> \
        --routes type=dict list=true destination=40.0.1.0/24,nexthop=10.1.0.10

Change-Id: I2a11486709e55d3143373858254febaabb93cfe8

commit_message:
Raising error if invalid attribute passed in.

400 will be returned when invalid attributes
are passed into Quantum API.

Fixed the some test cases failed since the
enforcement of invalid attribute checking

Fixes: bug #1076179

Change-Id: I4e9e2891c444f9dcd051f7b325d3c9403b28db86

commit_message:
support preallocated VM images

Use fallocate where available to allocate file system blocks efficiently
when the VM is initially provisioned. This will give immediate feedback
if enough space isn't available. Also it may significantly improve
performance on writes to new blocks, and may even improve I/O
performance to prewritten blocks due to reduced fragmentation.

Also noted is the potential to subsume the less general
libvirt_sparse_logical_volumes option into the new more general
preallocate_images option.

Implements bp: preallocated-images
Change-Id: I4bbb8616416c9dca3a3a8894ebf764a0b6b8dbc9

commit_message:
Add support for instance CPU consumption control.

Part 4 for blueprint quota-instance-resource, by setting cpu_shares,
cpu_quota,cpu_period through nova flavor-set with admin credentials,
 the cloud admin can implement flexable policy on VM vcpu to physical
CPU consumption ratio.

for example:
nova flavor-key m1.low_cpu set cpu_quota=10000
nova flavor-key m1.low_cpu set cpu_period=20000
the instance of m1.low_cpu can only has a max of 50% CPU consumption
of a physical CPU computing capability.

original reviews https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14151/
DocImpact
partly implement blueprint quota-instance-resource.

Change-Id: I9ea1229ee78a4d706b1a18c0f4f15157611952e4

- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/8344 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-18 10:05:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I understand the issue here, but what code is actually suffering problems because of this ? The libvirt driver uses tpool, but all that is run in the native thread is native libvirt API calls, so it won't be impacted by this problem, and I'm not seeing any reference to tpool in the DB code."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-02-18 14:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-02-18 15:56:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dave - The tpool use in DB will become evident when Chris gets our DB mysqldb backend stuff all posted up.  It'll have an option to turn on tpool usage so a single DB API call doesn't block the process. (with the native mysql DB driver)"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Just need to be careful that libraries and code we rely on doesn't make use of the bits of the thread module that were being monkey patched.  Something to be aware of when evaluating dependencies.

Code relying on 'thread' will get real OS threads now, right?

from eventlet/patcher.py:
    from eventlet.green import Queue
    from eventlet.green import thread
    from eventlet.green import threading
    return [('Queue', Queue), ('thread', thread), ('threading', threading)]"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:45:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Daniel:  Currently you can see dbpool which uses tpool) burried in openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/session.py. But it's broken there and moving.  See: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/22158/

Brian: It was using real OS threads before, but it was patching things so it could switch greenthreads too on threading locks, etc.  It's not much use for us in the way that we use tpool though IMO."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-02-18 20:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-19 01:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-19 01:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 01:33:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:47:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Isn't the point of monkey patching the threading module to ensure it plays well with greenthreads?

It seems like if we don't monkey patch threading anymore, it'll cause the main process to block when it used to switch to another greenthread, right?

Couldn't that cause deadlocks now if greenthreads switch because of a reason other than locks?

For instance:
  A acquires logging._lock
  A blocks on I/O
      switches to B
                B attempts to acquire logging._lock
      deadlock?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:50:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Possibly.  Unknown what is using threading.Lock().  logging happens to use an RLock which is reentrant... so it's fine.  But I understand your example."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:54:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(Trying to think of what might use threading.Lock while *also* using something patched by eventlet that would cause a greenthread switch.)   I guess we'll find out? ;)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have serious issues with choosing performance over correctness.

In this case it seems like we're opening up ourselves for deadlocks because we want to implement some performance improvements.

Even auditing our third party libraries won't ensure that future changes to those libraries won't introduce a hidden deadlock.

I really don't like this tradeoff."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 08:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-nova-docs/15362 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-nova-pep8/20759 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-nova-python26/16802 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-nova-python27/16866 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/3878 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/3600 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/22162/1/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/8310 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-19 09:37:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would also rather not see this change merged. The problem described in the commit message isn't really a bug IIUC - it is simply an inherent result mixing use of green threads & native threads. Avoiding patching of the thread module isn't fixing the problem - it is just turning it into a different problem which is arguably worse - now if 1 greenthread waits on a lock, all other greenthreads are blocked too. 

IMHO the only real thing we can do here is to make sure that code we run in a native thread tpool does not use the python logging modules, thus avoiding the locking problem. Basically only ever run individual native API calls in a native thread - never call any other python APIs from the native thread - leave all processing in the green threads."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-19 14:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I think there are too many outstanding concerns of correctness here to merge this late in the cycle. I get that microbenchmarks get better with this, but the safety concerns are pretty high.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-19 17:33:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Fair enough.  I'll work on finding the eventlet bug."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-20 07:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, only took most of the day. :) 

https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/pull-request/29/fix-use-of-semaphore-with-tpool-issue-137/diff'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-02-20 07:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Will wait to pull in a fix from eventlet somehow.'}]

Fixes bug 1128684

eventlet monkey patching the thread library doesn't play well when

common, because the python logging module uses them.

commit_message:
Do not eventlet.monkey_patch() the threading modules

Fixes bug 1128684

eventlet monkey patching the thread library doesn't play well when
tpool and threading locks are used.  Unfortunately use of the locks is
common, because the python logging module uses them.

This can be undone in the future if this is fixed:

https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/issue/137/use-of-threading-locks-causes-deadlock

Change-Id: Icd5d095576b4f9a59c0a5bcc4944fc07f3c56e80

commit_message:
Add support for instance disk IO control.

Part 3 for blueprint quota-instance-resource, by setting exposed params
"disk_read_bytes_sec, disk_read_iops_sec, disk_write_bytes_sec,
disk_write_iops_sec, disk_total_bytes_sec, disk_total_iops_sec"
through nova flavor-set, user can implement instance disk IO control
policy.
for example:
nova flavor-set m1.medium set disk_write_bytes_sec=10240000,
then the max disk write IO is 10MB/s for VM user.

partly implement blueprint quota-instance-resource
original reviews https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14151/
DocImpact

Change-Id: I8605acf61d7ddbfdaf6eee3ab135898df2449484

it and remove the copied-and-pasted version.

Add the 2013.1b3 tarball to tools/pip-requires - this will be changed

will happen in time for grizzly final.

Remove the 'deps = pep8==1.3.3' from tox.ini as it means all the other
deps get installed with easy_install which can't install oslo-config

commit_message:
Use oslo-config-2013.1b3

The cfg API is now available via the oslo-config library, so switch to
it and remove the copied-and-pasted version.

Add the 2013.1b3 tarball to tools/pip-requires - this will be changed
to 'oslo-config>=2013.1' when oslo-config is published to pypi. This
will happen in time for grizzly final.

Add dependency_links to setup.py so that oslo-config can be installed
from the tarball URL specified in pip-requires.

Remove the 'deps = pep8==1.3.3' from tox.ini as it means all the other
deps get installed with easy_install which can't install oslo-config
from the URL.

Retain dummy cfg.py file until keystoneclient middleware has been
updated (I18c450174277c8e2d15ed93879da6cd92074c27a).

Change-Id: I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc

commit_message:
Set rootwrap_config in cinder.conf sample.

Remove the root_helper=sudo in cinder.conf.sample and
move to the rootwrap_config=/etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf as
the default.

Change-Id: Ib4bacf4d24993cb9506b51523a5ba44fe1f85d18

commit_message:
Add support for network adapter hotplug.

    This patch makes it possible to add/del instance
    interface other than booting time.
    Implement bp:network-adapter-hotplug

Originally from change Ibee003a9ec6cc9b3fd275417caccd0c67f6c871f

Co-authored-by: Yaguang Tang <heut2008@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Ãdouard Thuleau <edouard.thuleau@orange.com>

Change-Id: I4f8f677af58afcb928379e5cf859388d1da45d51

Stack name only allow alphanumeric, hyphen and underscore characters

Add regex verification for [a-zA-Z][-_a-zA-Z0-9]*
It correspond to aws specification + underscores and "."

bug: 1103447

(1 inline comment)

I don't approve of this, Attila. Our naming convention for variables is to use all lowercase_with_underscores. This is the same convention used in all OpenStack projects.

I don't consider changing variable naming style to be cleanup."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-02 22:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@jaypipes:

This is not the important part, the server creation and deletion unification is more important.

I will rename them back.


IMHO matching the name to the request variables are important. I will add it to my list of what needs to be changed in the API :)'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-02 22:45:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-02 23:36:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-02-03 02:10:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

Some good cleanups in here now, thx Attila. However, please read my inline comments. There are a few places where I think we should keep the existing behaviour. Explanations in inline comments.

Best,
-jay"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-03 08:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If a server created in test_.* only waited when all other test_ case deleted. Deleting them just only tear-down is less efficient.

However waiting them, on after every test case is also unefficient. We need a blocked wait only, when we otherwise run out from the server resources.

If a test case does a waited delete, it just cause an additional unnecessary request in the base class.

I would not ignore them from the global listing, because in this case on exception they will not be deleted. 

I would not use possible "original exception killer" solution as well.

I do not want to address all wait/not wait related issues by this change. I just annotate them first.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Uniform compute test server creation

All compute test cases uses the create_server or create_server_no_wait
method from tempest/tests/compute/base.py.

We are one step closer to an uniform resource management.

Change-Id: If8f4dda4ca02e21c7ed38fa23d96d2a6af6994e0

1. validates if the port exists on the OVS when a port update event takes

   later updated by the agent when it is detected as up

commit_message:
OVS: update status according to admin_state_up

Fixes bug 1099099

In addition to this the code does the following:
1. validates if the port exists on the OVS when a port update event takes
   place
2. when a port is created the initial state is set as 'DOWN'. this is
   later updated by the agent when it is detected as up

Change-Id: I917d4b5aa8df7395fcaa841d77083546478739d2

commit_message:
Improves visual hierachy on Overview page

'Quota Summary' header has now the same styling
that the rest of headers in the application.

'Select a month to query its usage' form  is now
included in the 'Usage Summary' section.

Change-Id: Ib266359b374272ac126f81bfdc7151a2c7c41f1a
Implements: Improvements on Overview page
Fixes: bug #1100830

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-13 07:16:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21855/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/2465 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21855/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/6654 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-02-14 02:27:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I think the change is fine, but there is a bug and we should document that. (And record the info in the comment in devstack)."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-14 15:44:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

so I dug into the problem with ComputeCapabilitiesFilter a bit more, and the problem is that we're specifying deploy_[kernel|ramdisk]_id on the instance_type extra_specs, but we're *not* advertising the same values within the baremetal driver.

The CCB is there to ensure that extra_specs:cpu_arch is matched properly, and it does this quite well (we probably don't need that check inside the hypervisor driver, actually).

The solution to this apparent bug is to amend the [baremetal] instance_type_extra_specs config option with the uuid's of the deploy images. However, in devstack, nova must have started before we generate those uuid's... chicken-vs-egg..."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-14 15:50:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-14 17:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21855/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/2808 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21855/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/2534 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/21855/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/7051 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-02-14 20:03:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Would this be simpler to solve if the baremetal calls were not nested inside the nova functions but stand-alone like the other services?'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-14 23:26:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Dean,

I don't think it makes sense for baremetal to be a separate service -- it's a driver for nova-compute, and takes the place of libvirt/xen/etc.

However, I got to thinking, why do we really need nova-compute(baremetal) running before we generate the deploy image IDs? I think we dont. We need to load those images into glance to generate their UUIDs, and we need to pass those UUIDs to nova-compute. We can pass them either as config options or as instance_type extra_specs (the latter method breaks CCFilter).

So what do you think - is it safe to start g-reg before n-cpu?"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:29:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I wasn't thinking it would look like a service, just to separate the calls to have a bit more control over the order of events.

Glance already is completely up before Nova, although the steps are interleaved the service is started earlier.  Remember, the order they appear in screen is the order they started.

FWIW, I've been thinking about reordering stack.sh so it does most if not all of a services work before starting the next one.  I'm bringing them up that way in Grenade and I think I like it better."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Great! So, if the line

  upload_baremetal_deploy $TOKEN

could be moved to before n-cpu is configured, then the config line that I am changing in this patch would become

  iniset $NOVA_CONF baremetal instance_type_extra_specs cpu_arch:$BM_CPU_ARCH,deploy_kernel:$BM_DEPLOY_KERNEL_ID,deploy_ramdisk:$BM_DEPLOY_RAMDISK_ID

and then within lib/baremetal create_baremetal_flavor(), we skip setting the deploy_kernel_id and deploy_ramdisk_id. I think with those changes, CCFilter should work.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-15 12:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-02-18 20:34:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The alternative you propose sounds a lot better.

@Dean, have you considered switching stack.sh into Make, to get parallelism of github downloads and the like?"}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-18 21:28:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-02-18 21:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Changed comment to reference a bug in Nova.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-02-18 21:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-18 22:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Baremetal should start using scheduler filters.

The baremetal driver should start using scheduler filters, particularly
the RetryFilter and ComputeFilter, as some functionality in Nova depends
on these.

However, the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter currently does not work with
baremetal in devstack due to an order-of-operations issue, so we
explicitly list the other filters that we do want.

Change-Id: Icc4b074c6f99e3e4ffbcf5eef0f9bb6f0f5c1996

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Restored

still waiting for the nova patch to land...'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-04 23:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Waiting for the nova patch to land in Nova.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-05 18:59:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm surprised that other setup and config things aren't required for this to work."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-05 19:38:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This change simply adds the required packages for the nova compute code to work properly.   The nova changes need sysfstools (systool) and sg3-utils (sginfo)  in order to support fibre Channel.   The nova code optionally can do multipath as well, but it's not required.

No setup/configuration is needed for sysfstools and sg3-utils to work properly.   

A user will need Fibre Channel HBAs in the system for Fibre Channel to actually work.  But that is outside the scope of devstack."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-02-05 20:36:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:13:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Unless devstack is specifically testing this code, I don't think these need to be added.  In fact, I think it's important that the code work perfectly fine without them."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:15:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Devstack works just fine without them, but not if you want to use Fibre Channel.  If you are a developer that wants to write a new cinder volume Fibre Channel driver, you need these packages installed with devstack.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-19 15:05:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ok sure, that makes sense.  Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-19 17:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:10:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Ready For Review

I'll +2 it later this week, rather not consume any CI resources right now that aren't needed"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-20 03:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Add Nova fibre channel support required packages

This patch is to support the nova patch that adds
Fibre Channel support to nova.  Fibre Channel requires
sysfsutils, sg3-utils, multipath-tools

Change-Id: I9e44ef9152f1916b245dba3be77076f0283fed44

commit_message:
Fix IPC direct topic routing.

Direct messages were being stripped of the host
value when performing IPC forwarding. This caused
direct topics to be round-robined to all
services running on the system consuming from
the same base topic name.

i.e. if 'scheduler.host1' and 'scheduler.host2'
were running on the SAME machine, messages to
'scheduler.host1' may have been routed to
'scheduler.host2'.

Now, mulitple processing specifying different
rpc_zmq_host parameters will consume on
separate direct topics and will not
round-robin to other processes.

Adds a zmq-specific test to ensure that messages to
directed topics are not consumed by other
consumers of direct topics sharing a bare
topic on the same host.

Fixes bug 1123715

Change-Id: I939c24397e58492fc16561666aed3ca891325e9c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-20 02:21:24.000000000', 'message': "Setup exception handler after configuring logging.

We currently set up the exc handler before we configure logging.
This means that an error in the setup will try to raise an exception
which will then fail to log properly because we haven't set up
handlers properly yet. Therefore, simply rely on the default
exception handler during setup and setup our exception handler
immediately after logging is configured.

Fixes bug 1130464

Change-Id: I4b80c646a7d7d5048c8fbadc67dbb9f607d2af69
"}]
commit_message:
Setup exception handler after configuring logging.

We currently set up the exc handler before we configure logging.
This means that an error in the setup will try to raise an exception
which will then fail to log properly because we haven't set up
handlers properly yet. Therefore, simply rely on the default
exception handler during setup and setup our exception handler
immediately after logging is configured.

Fixes bug 1130464

Change-Id: I4b80c646a7d7d5048c8fbadc67dbb9f607d2af69

commit_message:
Add Quantum support for NVP Layer-2 gateways

Blueprint nvp-nwgw-api

This patch adds an API extension, the relevant DB logic, and the NVP
plugin logic for managing a NVP-specific feature, Layer-2 Network
Gateway, through the Quantum API.
The proposed extension is meant to be used with the NVP plugin only.

Change-Id: I73a8f1782c345ca7f6dec2db36ba6f9299b30d04

[{'created': '2013-02-11 19:06:17.000000000', 'message': "Recapture screen service logs; disable sysloging.

Using syslog as the single point of OpenStack service data when running
devstack-gate is clunky. Exception tracebacks are compressed into a
single line making it hard to read what broke. Return to capturing
individual screen logs, but don't duplicate those logs to syslog
anymore.

Change-Id: I17e31b4ffde00bb57f70129710c1b6bb1584a5fa
"}]
commit_message:
Recapture screen service logs; disable sysloging.

Using syslog as the single point of OpenStack service data when running
devstack-gate is clunky. Exception tracebacks are compressed into a
single line making it hard to read what broke. Return to capturing
individual screen logs, but don't duplicate those logs to syslog
anymore.

Change-Id: I17e31b4ffde00bb57f70129710c1b6bb1584a5fa

commit_message:
libvirt: Use uuid for instance directory name

This is done in a backwards compatible manner to deal with instances
started under the old regieme where we used a less unique name.

Resolves bug 1023865.

Change-Id: I4c9b7b291a30a7f3c2c9305c8fa346dc582bee88

"}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2013-02-16 00:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The problem here is that under the deps list for pep8 in tox.ini only pep8 is listed. This means that pip is only used to install pep8. Then tox runs sdist install on glance which attempts to install all of the dependencies using easy_install. easy_install does not grok the tarball url and dies.

You can fix this by removing the "deps = pep8==1.3.3" line under [testenv:pep8] (this causes it to inherit the deps list form [testenv].'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-16 14:43:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-16 14:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Use oslo-config-2013.1b3

The cfg API is now available via the oslo-config library, so switch to
it and remove the copied-and-pasted version.

Add the 2013.1b3 tarball to tools/pip-requires - this will be changed
to 'oslo-config>=2013.1' when oslo-config is published to pypi. This
will happen in time for grizzly final.

Remove the 'deps = pep8==1.3.3' from tox.ini as it means all the other
deps get installed with easy_install which can't install oslo-config
from the URL.

Retain dummy cfg.py file until keystoneclient middleware has been
updated (I18c450174277c8e2d15ed93879da6cd92074c27a).

Change-Id: I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc

commit_message:
Added a service heartbeat driver using Memcached.

Today the heartbeat information of Nova services/nodes
is maintained in the DB, while each service updates the
corresponding record in the Service table periodically
(by default -- every 10 seconds), specifying the timestamp
of the last update. This mechanism is highly inefficient
and does not scale. E.g., maintaining the heartbeat
information for 1,000 nodes/services would require 100 DB
updates per second (just for the heartbeat).

This patch adds nova.servicegroup.drivers.memcached, a
service heartbeat driver using Memcached. You can reduce
DB updates with it.

blueprint memcached-service-heartbeat

Change-Id: I60bdb1cfbce1fea051f276ebfd6ccc4ad8fe6d2b

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-19 02:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I'm pretty sure you can't edit .po files like this -- they're provided by a translation company."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2013-02-19 03:02:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The way we do translation syncing is:
For each commit that merges we do an extract and update catalog. We then copy the resulting .pot and .po files to transifex to update transifex with these results.

Then once a day grab the .po files that translators have created on transifex and shove them into the project and if there are significant changes submit them for review to Gerrit.

Assuming that this change is based on a relatively new master updating the .po files in a change should be ok.

There is some thought that we should make the importation go one direction only (transifex -> nova etc) to simplify things but today we don't do that."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-19 03:03:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

I stand corrected.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-19 03:05:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-12 11:46:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This seems like a really manually way to solve this problem, that's quite error prone. It also adds another config variable that needs to be right for an environment to work as people expect. Is there a way to auto detect those networks instead and build the snat rule that way?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:39:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sean: unfortunately we don't keep track of a range for floating ips, they are just individual ips in the database, so we can't detect the value for the network unless we want to create a separate rule for every floating ip.

Note that we already have a (badly named) similar parameter for the opposite functionality: dmz_cidr. The dmz_cidr config is a list of ranges that we want to skip snatting for. I was considering deprecating dmz_cidr and replacing it with a matching skip_snat_range to have some symmetry, but it seems silly to deprecate a config in code that we are hoping to eventually leave behind.

Note that the skip_snat (dmz_cidr) can be done with an iptables rule, but the force_snat requires ebtables because the packet needs to be forced to route to hit the snat rule properly.

I suspect this will be a little used option because it is only useful in a very specific (non-default) config, so most people can simply ignore it."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-12 22:20:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

if we could live without this it would be nice, especially to do something smarter with ranges and not add another config variable. It's sort of a shame that we loose the user supplied input for fixed and floating ranges as they are sent in. What if we captured and kept that instead somewhere (yes, realizing a new table is probably equally messy as a new config, but at least it's living state), and for existing users just make them rerun their network definitions to fill out that?"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-02-18 20:49:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is a decent way to do this. It's a bit messy, but it works.

Sean, I'd say let's merge this now so things work. If you have a better solution in the future, "patches accepted".'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-18 21:03:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not going to object, though it smells funny to me because of the new conf variable. I'll let someone else +2 it."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-19 21:55:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 22:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

[{'created': '2013-02-11 20:54:21.000000000', 'message': 'Allow fixed to float ping with external gateway.

instance with the floating ip. The source address will be on the fixed
network, so if the floating addresses are on a different network, the
receiving host to drop the packet due to the default rp_filter.
Essentially, the route for the fixed range is on a different interface
so it the kernel assumes the packet is spoofed and drops it.

In order to fix this issue this patch adds a new config option called
force_snat_range. Traffic that originates in fixed_range and has a
destination in force_snat_range will always be routed. This forces
the packet to hit the fallback floating roule and be snatted to
routing_source_ip. This means the traffic will originate from the
proper network and the packet will make it through.

DocImpact

Fixes bug 1122335

commit_message:
Allow fixed to float ping with external gateway.

If you ping an a floating ip from an instance with only a fixed ip, the
traffic will be sent to the default gateway. If the default gateway has
a route to the floating ip, it will then be sent to the host of the
instance with the floating ip. The source address will be on the fixed
network, so if the floating addresses are on a different network, the
receiving host to drop the packet due to the default rp_filter.
Essentially, the route for the fixed range is on a different interface
so it the kernel assumes the packet is spoofed and drops it.

In order to fix this issue this patch adds a new config option called
force_snat_range. Traffic that originates in fixed_range and has a
destination in force_snat_range will always be routed. This forces
the packet to hit the fallback floating roule and be snatted to
routing_source_ip. This means the traffic will originate from the
proper network and the packet will make it through.

DocImpact

Fixes bug 1122335

Change-Id: I7e31c25d37a5c4fd02c8238aec58a28af3fd7f6a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-15 20:22:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix LXC container creation

Recent changes to the blockdev creation introduced in
7be531fe9462f2b07d4a1abf6687f649d1dfbb89 caused a regression
when LXC containers were being created.

When the image is being fetched from glance, the disk mappings
for the disk bus, disk information, etc is checked before being
copied. However since LXC does not understand this concept it was
not passing any information, so the image was never being copied.

Send some basic information about the disk when the instance is being
created in order for the image to begin. Fixes LP: #1126348

Change-Id: I90daf853903737013be0cd23f78c7f61e4e15a77
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Fix LXC container creation

Recent changes to the blockdev creation introduced in
7be531fe9462f2b07d4a1abf6687f649d1dfbb89 caused a regression
when LXC containers were being created.

When the image is being fetched from glance, the disk mappings
for the disk bus, disk information, etc is checked before being
copied. However since LXC does not understand this concept it was
not passing any information, so the image was never being copied.

Send some basic information about the disk when the instance is being
created in order for the image to begin. Fixes LP: #1126348

Change-Id: I90daf853903737013be0cd23f78c7f61e4e15a77
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fix XMLMatcher error reporting

The nova.tests.matchers.XMLMismatch class implements the
get_details() method returning a dictionary with the expect
and actual XML output. It is returning a string values, but
the testtools code requires that the dictionary values are
instances of the testtools.content.Content object.

To quote the 'get_details' docs on testtools.matchers.Mismatch

     :return: a dict mapping names to Content objects. name is a string to
         name the detail, and the Content object is the detail to add
         to the result. For more information see the API to which items from
         this dict are passed testtools.TestCase.addDetail.

Related bug #1130146
Change-Id: I75ec07d8b34b04c7b8009229fda49b344ed13bec
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix XML config tests for disk/net/cpu tuning

Due to a bug in the XML matching code, some XML formatting
problems related to disk/net/cpu tuning were not flaged as
errors. The problems were all simply ordering of the elements.
This patch also fixes some indentation problems at the same time

Fixes bug #1130146
Change-Id: Iee392ed823002b8231b33c27b487c2538b2dc8cd
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Are these new packages installed automatically as part of Nova install or is it user's responsibility to install them?  Are they required for Cinder as well?  Thanks."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-22 16:50:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

xing,   I have a patch in review for devstack that automatically installs sysfsutils and sg3-utils.  Multipath has some issues with the jenkins build jobs, but I believe I have a fix for that as well.   Once this patch lands in Nova, the devstack patch will get reviewed.

For the time being, you will have to manually install the 
sysfsutils, sg3-utils packages.   The multipath package is optional.

on ubuntu
apt-getinstall sysfsutil sg3-utils.

Whoever is maintaining the rpms, deb packages for nova will have to add those 2 as deps.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-22 17:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think there's way too much code being added to libvirt/volume.py here. Most of the code is not at all specific to libvirt and thus would be better in a standalone module "nova/storage/linuxscsi.py" or something like that. Then the libvirt volume.py impl would just call out to suitable APIs todo its work'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-22 17:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I presume you are talking about the code in volume.py:LibvirtFibreChannelVolumeDriver ?

I suppose I could pull some of that out into a generic libscsi.py, but the only code using it would be the FC volume driver.   There are only 4 small methods for doing scsi work, the other method is for multipath work.  The multipath method wouldn't belong in the libscsi.py."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-25 22:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-25 22:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

I'm afraid you lost the race with one of my changes, so you're going to need to rebase this, and move the 'test_libvirt.py' test cases you added into the new 'test_libvirt_volume.py' file"}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-02-06 13:54:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This patch has two problems for me.  The FC HBA I used is: QLogic Corp. ISP2422-based 4Gb Fibre Channel to PCI-X HBA

I put one problem in the inline comments.  The second problem is that the code to scan/remove devices is finding 'stale' devices for some reason.  For example:
1. create vol1 and vol2
2. map vol1
3. unmap vol1
4. map vol2

If the two volumes will get the same LUN number, there will be confusion and I will get a device file that points to vol1 and gives I/O errors.

I think that if this code goes through, there will need to be some documentation about which HBAs and controllers were tested and what is supported.

I will try later today with a different HBA."}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-02-06 20:13:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

We traced the stale entry problem to unclean shutdown of OpenStack and deleting the volume on the storage controller, which led to inconsistent state (the kernel still had a record of the device).  It would be nice to have a fix, but this is no longer a show-stopper as far as I'm concerned.  I successfully tested the patch, and it will have my +1 as soon as the path issue that I mentioned is fixed.  I still recommend publishing some documentation about HBAs tested.  Thanks for this great work!"}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-07 00:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-02-07 00:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-18 00:41:21.000000000', 'message': "Fibre channel block storage support (nova changes)

implements blueprint libvirt-fibre-channel

These changes constitute the required libvirt changes to
support attaching Fibre Channel volumes to a VM.

This requires a few new packages to be available on the system
sg3-utils -- this package is needed for scsi device discovery
multipath -- This package is needed for multipath support.

Typical Fibre Channel arrays support exporting volumes via
multiple ports, so multipath support is highly desirable
for fault tolerance.  If multipath is not installed,
the new FibreChannel libvirt volume driver will still work.

If multipath is enabled, the new Fibre Channel volume driver
detects each of the attached devices for the volume, and
properly removes every one of them on detach.

In order to use this, the cinder volume driver's
initialize_connection will simply return a dictionary
with a new driver_volume_type called 'fibrechan'.

The target_wwn can be a single entry or a list of wwns
that correspond to the list of remote wwn(s) that will
export the volume.

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibrechan',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': '1234567890123'}}

or

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibrechan',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': ['1234567890123',
                                '0987654321321']}}

Change-Id: Ifccc56f960ef434f7cb56a9367e4cad288358440

The target_wwn can be a single entry or a list of wwns
that correspond to the list of remote wwn(s) that will
export the volume.

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibrechan',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': '1234567890123'}}

or

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibrechan',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': ['1234567890123',
                                '0987654321321']}}

Change-Id: Ifccc56f960ef434f7cb56a9367e4cad288358440
"}, {'created': '2013-02-14 19:34:22.000000000', 'message': "Fibre channel block storage support (nova changes)

support attaching Fibre Channel volumes to a VM.

multipath -- This package is needed for multipath support.

Typical Fibre Channel arrays support exporting volumes via
multiple ports, so multipath support is highly desirable
for fault tolerance.  If multipath is not installed,
the new FibreChannel libvirt volume driver will still work.

detects each of the attached devices for the volume, and
properly removes every one of them on detach.

commit_message:
Fibre channel block storage support (nova changes)

implements blueprint libvirt-fibre-channel

These changes constitute the required libvirt changes to
support attaching Fibre Channel volumes to a VM.

This requires a few new packages to be available on the system
sysfsutils -- This is needed to discover the FC HBAs
sg3-utils -- this package is needed for scsi device discovery
multipath -- This package is needed for multipath support.

Typical Fibre Channel arrays support exporting volumes via
multiple ports, so multipath support is highly desirable
for fault tolerance.  If multipath is not installed,
the new FibreChannel libvirt volume driver will still work.

If multipath is enabled, the new Fibre Channel volume driver
detects each of the attached devices for the volume, and
properly removes every one of them on detach.

In order to use this, the cinder volume driver's
initialize_connection will simply return a dictionary
with a new driver_volume_type called 'fibrechan'.

The target_wwn can be a single entry or a list of wwns
that correspond to the list of remote wwn(s) that will
export the volume.

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibre_channel',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': '1234567890123'}}

or

return {'driver_volume_type': 'fibre_channel',
        'data': {'target_lun', 1,
                 'target_wwn': ['1234567890123',
                                '0987654321321']}}

Change-Id: Ifccc56f960ef434f7cb56a9367e4cad288358440

commit_message:
Fix "DirectConsumer needs mirrored queue support"

Currently TopicCosumer and FanoutConsumer can be used
Mirrored Queue support, but not DirectConsumer.
This patch fix this issue.

Fix bug 1124162

Change-Id: I68ae23467ae810ce0ec917a4cb34a488283f401c

commit_message:
Fast serialization of RPC envelopes for Kombu

By flattening the dictionary and turning
it into a fast-serialized string, we save
ourselves from Kombu's very slow JSON serialization
routines.

Change-Id: I64796265c7cc89a05406faabd8d7b253fe3b8acb

Problems with 'test_notification_envelope', still looking into it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-10 18:20:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-10 18:29:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I don't see the need for sub-envelope and don't know why you don't make the change such that everything can be done in the common serialize_msg and deserialize_msg."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-10 18:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

While we're not actually doing so at the moment, it seemed reasonable that we might want a method that can be used to verify messages when there is no intention to deserialize them.  Putting the verification in a function called "deserialize_msg" just seemed wrong to me. However, there is no other reason this cannot be part of deserialize_msg.

Per the envelope change:

It seems generally preferable that we do not modify message contents as provided by the developer. In fact, these messages may not be type(dict) but may be str, list, or some other type.

Using legacy messaging, we have no choice but to modify the user's message to maintain compatibility via '_envelope_params'.

The reason I'm adding a sub_envelope is because the 'id' needs to be serialized and hashed together with the message. There are also other key/vals that I intend to add here.

See below for my mailing-list post noting these intentions:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-January/005290.html'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-11 16:39:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Eric wrote: While we're not actually doing so at the moment, it seemed reasonable that we might want a method that can be used to verify messages when there is no intention to deserialize them.

Please elaborate on a case where we would want to verify a message, but not process it?  I don't see it or if it exists it seems like it is a corner case in which we wouldn't care about performance.

Eric wrote:  Putting the verification in a function called "deserialize_msg" just seemed wrong to me. However, there is no other reason this cannot be part of deserialize_msg.

We could just rename them process_outgoing_msg() and process_incoming_msg().  It is just cleaner to have all the code in one place.  It seems like a good place for putting other common features.

Eric wrote: It seems generally preferable that we do not modify message contents as provided by the developer.

I am suggesting that the new content be placed in the existing envelope as opposed to creating a new envelope.  I was of the understanding that the new envelope was created for that purpose.  Why create a sub-envelope?

Eric wrote: In fact, these messages may not be type(dict) but may be str, list, or some other type.

The contract that seems clearly defined in common/rpc/__init__.py is that every RPC call that exists today requires that the input be a dict().  For backward compatibility we can simply add the new verification to the base dict() msg and then on the receiving side detect whether the message was wrapped in an envelope and pull the verification information from the envelope.  Otherwise, take it from the base msg.  Note that RPC already adds msg_id to the base msg.  There is no precedent being made by expanding what we put in the message.


Eric wrote: The reason I'm adding a sub_envelope is because the 'id' needs to be serialized and hashed together with the message. There are also other key/vals that I intend to add here.

I think you could still add a 'trusted_msg' key to the existing envelope whose value is a dict with all the goodies you want for trusted messaging.  If you want to compute a hash on the msg and some additional values you could just compute the has on {'id': <id>, 'msg': <message>} and not make that structure actually be what is sent on the wire.  Just create it for hash computation.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-11 17:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

[Ray Wrote: I am suggesting that the new content be placed in the existing envelope as opposed to creating a new envelope. I was of the understanding that the new envelope was created for that purpose. Why create a sub-envelope?]

Because the user-specified message needs to be serialized and hashed together with other variables. The only alternative to this would be to edit the message itself, which I still am not convinced is a viable path.

[Ray Wrote: The contract that seems clearly defined in common/rpc/__init__.py is that every RPC call that exists today requires that the input be a dict(). For backward compatibility we can simply add the new verification to the base dict() msg and then on the receiving side detect whether the message was wrapped in an envelope and pull the verification information from the envelope. Otherwise, take it from the base msg. Note that RPC already adds msg_id to the base msg. There is no precedent being made by expanding what we put in the message.]

Actually, this is not true. The AMQP message replies are not type(dict). I'm not too certain about notifications, but aren't they developer-defined types?

[Ray Wrote: I think you could still add a 'trusted_msg' key to the existing envelope whose value is a dict with all the goodies you want for trusted messaging. If you want to compute a hash on the msg and some additional values you could just compute the has on {'id': <id>, 'msg': <message>} and not make that structure actually be what is sent on the wire. Just create it for hash computation.]

The problem is that you can't compute a hash on a dictionary. This data needs to be serialized. Either we serialize it once, or we serialize it twice. Now, it could be that we have an envelope key of (say) 'trusted_msg', serialize its value, and then manually hack additional JSON around both serialized pieces so they become a single, unified JSON blob.

That isn't very clean or intuitive, though."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-11 21:49:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Eric Wrote: The AMQP message replies are not type(dict).

The AMQP replies are a dict, for example: {'result': reply, 'failure': failure}

Eric Wrote: I'm not too certain about notifications, but aren't they developer-defined types?

Read common/rpc/__init__.py.  It clearly states that the input for each type of RPC is a dict.

Eric wrote: The problem is that you can't compute a hash on a dictionary. This data needs to be serialized. Either we serialize it once, or we serialize it twice. Now, it could be that we have an envelope key of (say) 'trusted_msg', serialize its value, and then manually hack additional JSON around both serialized pieces so they become a single, unified JSON blob.

I'm not totally convinced.  It appears hashlib has some nice functionality that allows you to add strings to the hash using an append() method.  Here's a quote from the docs: "You can now feed this object with arbitrary strings using the update() method. At any point you can ask it for the digest of the concatenation of the strings fed to it so far using the digest() or hexdigest() methods." from http://docs.python.org/2/library/hashlib.html'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-11 22:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

When I say hash, I do not mean through the use of hashlib. The message signing library must be able to treat the entire message being signed as a string (or possibly even as an IO).'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:50:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Ray: re-evaluating a bit, yes, I can just concat the JSON blobs and won't need to make such valid JSON. I'm still not sure why we shouldn't just make a sub-envelope though, since it seems that envelope backwards compatibility is a non-issue at the moment.

Not combining these into a sub-envelope can cause some complexity around message encryption, when/if we get to it."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:53:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

This patch puts everything into serialize_msg and deserialize_msg and concats two JSON blobs from adjacent fields in the envelope.

I'm still not keen on this approach for the aforementioned reasons. I'd like to get additional review/feedback."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:59:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/21562/5/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/690 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21562/5/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/987 : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-12 20:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-12 21:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21562/6/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/693 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21562/6/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/989 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/21562/6/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/989 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-13 00:28:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (4 inline comments)

I think it is cleaner this way.  And I thought the purpose of the envelope was to have a place for new things. I hate to think that every time we come up with something new, we would need to add another sub-sub-...-sub-envelope.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-13 01:46:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

[Ray wrote: And I thought the purpose of the envelope was to have a place for new things]

Yes, but top-level elements of the envelope aren't serialized. More importantly, they're not serialized together. Having the ability to have fields that are not serialized together is good as we'll need a place for the signature itself, for example. However, those fields that are signed together need to be either in a single serialized field, or concatenated together.

Simply concatenating fields won't work for encryption, although we could rev a backwards-incompatible message format for that if/when we get there.

[Ray wrote: I hate to think that every time we come up with something new, we would need to add another sub-sub-...-sub-envelope.]

Even if we had keys in the sub-envelope that had dict-type values, that wouldn't be a bad thing. The point is that they'd be serialized together and we wouldn't need to make a breaking change to make that happen. With the current patch-set, this feature is simply moved to a separate field within the larger envelope.

Besides compatibility with a message format that has never actually been used, the only value I can see of keeping the oslo.hash-params field separate from the oslo.message field is that we can separately deserialize the oslo-hash-params field, without unpacking the potentially large message content field. It remains to be seen if that would be useful."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-13 02:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

In-line replies.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-13 03:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Fix key check in instance actions formatter.

The 'key in object' check doesn't work for sqlalchemy models so nothing
was getting copied over during the format.  This patch switches to using
get() to retrieve a value.

Bug 1126593

Change-Id: I726c2a624928247de41a077c23fe80742cbf9044

This new rpc method was not ensuring that the result was converted to
primitive types.  This would cause it to break when using an rpc backend
other than impl_kombu.

Change-Id: I0a21b559d12ff7d0c96341fcec887b2436753eda
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure rpc result is primitive types.

This new rpc method was not ensuring that the result was converted to
primitive types.  This would cause it to break when using an rpc backend
other than impl_kombu.

Change-Id: I0a21b559d12ff7d0c96341fcec887b2436753eda

commit_message:
Support running periodic tasks immediately at startup

This change adds a parameter to allow periodic tasks that would
otherwise have to wait for a lengthy initial interval to run immediately
when the periodic tasks are started. This patch also applies the new
facility in the the _sync_power_states task in the compute manager to
get more timely access to Openstack server state when the compute node
starts up.

Change-Id: I461a5dbaa7d18919941ec31402910eef188d8e8c

commit_message:
Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Nova modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282 for Essex.

Change-Id: I815b27ff2845293e3d6771ff8f99944ec08ccbd5

commit_message:
Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Nova modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282 for Folsom.

Change-Id: I6a4051b5e66f3ce5a330b2589c42e6e9e5b9268e

[{'created': '2013-02-19 22:38:23.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using cfg in install_venv_common

Several people have complained that requiring oslo-config to be
installed in order to run install_venv seems like a chicken and egg
problem.

We're only using cfg for a boolean CLI option which is way overkill.
The truth is that cfg is really only interesting if you want to process
options from both the command line and configuration files. Clearly
that's not the case here.

Just use argparse instead of cfg.

Change-Id: Ib602686b554c3548f4be3d4a69d128c5fef7e8cf
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid using cfg in install_venv_common

Several people have complained that requiring oslo-config to be
installed in order to run install_venv seems like a chicken and egg
problem.

We're only using cfg for a boolean CLI option which is way overkill.
The truth is that cfg is really only interesting if you want to process
options from both the command line and configuration files. Clearly
that's not the case here.

Just use argparse instead of cfg.

Change-Id: Ib602686b554c3548f4be3d4a69d128c5fef7e8cf

commit_message:
Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Cinder modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282 for Folsom.

Change-Id: Ie8ae7a6e12fbf51de406d10ca21072140374abf5

commit_message:
Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Cinder modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282.

Change-Id: Iff8340033c8e8db58184944a1bf705e16b8b3e03

commit_message:
HP 3PAR Fibre Channel Driver and iSCSI Updates

This is the initial FC driver for the HP 3PAR array, along with some
3PAR iSCSI driver cleanup and changes in the HP 3PAR common class.
Summary of changes:
* Initial FC Driver for the Grizzly release (depends on the FC base class
  and nova FC changes https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19992/ &
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20003/)
* Updates to iSCSI Driver include volume type and create clone volume support
  as well as general cleanup(comments, copyright, minor bug fixes).
* The tests have been updated to add FC test and the file was renamed
  to reflect both FC and iSCSI 3PAR tests.
* Volume types added for the Grizzly release include cpg, snap_cpg, persona
  and provisioning(thin vs. full)

Partially Implements: blueprint fibre-channel-block-storage

Change-Id: Ie1c2e755aa1bcd5994ea4b02674718721b958e07
