revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-13 19:49:58.000000000', 'message': "Fibre Channel base class for Cinder drivers

This is the base class, FibreChannelDriver, for all fibre channel
drivers to extend. Currently, it has only initialize_connection
with comments, but this will be a place to put common functions
similar to the iSCSI base class.

This patch depends on the following nova and devstack changes
to be functional(both still in the review process but approved
for Grizzly):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19992/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20003/

This patch does not support copy_image_to_volume and
copy_volume_to_image in the Grizzly release. We'll revisit
this in Havana and add that support.

Partially Implements: blueprint fibre-channel-block-storage

Change-Id: I8bd28b8bd96deaec1db219457f407169ed172f69
"}, {'created': '2013-02-19 17:57:08.000000000', 'message': "Fibre Channel base class for Cinder drivers

This is the base class, FibreChannelDriver, for all fibre channel
drivers to extend. Currently, it has only initialize_connection
with comments, but this will be a place to put common functions
similar to the iSCSI base class.

This patch depends on the following nova and devstack changes
to be functional(both still in the review process but approved
for Grizzly):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19992/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20003/

This patch does not support copy_image_to_volume and
copy_volume_to_image in the Grizzly release. We'll revisit
this in Havana and add that support.

Partially Implements: blueprint fibre-channel-block-storage

Change-Id: I8bd28b8bd96deaec1db219457f407169ed172f69
"}]
commit_message:
Fibre Channel base class for Cinder drivers

This is the base class, FibreChannelDriver, for all fibre channel
drivers to extend. Currently, it has only initialize_connection
with comments, but this will be a place to put common functions
similar to the iSCSI base class.

This patch depends on the following nova and devstack changes
to be functional(both still in the review process but approved
for Grizzly):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19992/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20003/

This patch does not support copy_image_to_volume and
copy_volume_to_image in the Grizzly release. We'll revisit
this in Havana and add that support.

Partially Implements: blueprint fibre-channel-block-storage

Change-Id: I8bd28b8bd96deaec1db219457f407169ed172f69

commit_message:
Default SG rules for the Security Group "Default"

Added in the API os-security-group-default-rules

This allows create, delete, list, and get (of individual rules) for
rules that will be pre-populated into the Security Group "default"
that is populated in all projects on creation.

These rules will not be applied retroactively, as it is designed
to allow the creation of a "reasonable" base-line set of sg rules.

The new rules live in a separate table that mirrors the relevant
structures of the security_group_rules table.

Added unit tests/API samples for the new API calls

Related to bp default-rules-for-default-security-group

DocImpact

Change-Id: I7ab51e68aff562bb869538197a0eca158fc3220c

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This work is valuable to the good direction, but we need to consider API backward compatibility. This patch changes v2.0 API behavior. I posted the detail to the dev ML.

This is the reason I add -1 for it.

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (22 inline comments)

Hello, the code isn't bad at all, and for this reason I am approving, scheduling completion for grizzly-3.

However, beyond the implementation comments inline, there are two topics we still need to discuss:

1) Plugin interface compatibility: this is something I asked for earlier on, but I wasn't quite prepared to move towards versioning of the plugin interface; which, from what I gather, is the direction you're moving towards. I find your code interesting, especially for the effort you're making with compatibility wrappers. However, we need a larger consensus before introducing plugin versioning. Hence, I will bring this discussion to the mailing list. Nevertheless, I would consider, if you haven't already done so, an approach where the API asks the plugin if pagination is supported, and, in that case, passes in the parameters for pagination; in negative case (pagination not supported) we can either raise or emulate it in the api layer as we do for bulk requests

2) I am not sure about the current solutions for sorting responses. I have checked nova and glance APIs, and from your analysis and official docs it does not seem they expose sorting to users. However, I think that separating the parameters for the key and the sort direction might be confusing, especially as often users assume 'ascending' as the default direction. Instead of the approach you're proposing can we have key and direction in the same parameter, for instance sort=<param_name>::{ASC|DESC} where ASC is the default choice?"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (6 inline comments)

Some answers to Alex'x questions."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (22 inline comments)

Salvatore, thank you for your review!

1) Plugin interface compatibility: I agree with you this code need a larger consensus and hard to get agree on. Your suggestion is reasonable. We can implement pagination same as the implement of bulk. And emulate pagination when plugin didn't support is good suggestion. Let me try this. Thanks for your suggestion!

2) Yes, nova didn't expose sorting to user. I just think we expose it to user, then user can have more option. I agree with your suggestion about merge sort_key and sort_dir in one parameter."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Doesn't seem to work

Hi Alex,

From a functional perspective the code is great, and there are no bw compatibility concerns. 
The only things I noticed is that we still have a link to 'previous' even if there are no previous data, which can be tolerated I guess; also, I saw the dhcp agent sending the requests that triggered the warning 'sort isn't any primary key'. This does not look great, but I think it's not causing issues. You can fix it in this patch or in a separate one.

Finally, your addition of primary_key to the resource attr info might be problematic for extensions which do not specify any (such as loadbalancer) or for 'out of tree' extensions. See comment inline for more info."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (9 inline comments)

Hi Alex

I got it for emulated testing.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: (17 inline comments)

Salvatore, Nachi, Thanks!

@Salvatore, Did you say when you request as '?limit=x', you can see previous page link in the first page? I think that is more nature behavior. Because when you get even number page, you also will see an next link before the last empty page. That is same with first page.

example:
request with '?limit=2' and you have 4 items, you can get 3 pages and last page was empty.

That is same with request as 'limit=2&page_reverse=True'

I also can remove that link if you think this doesn't make sense."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Salvatore, thanks for the note

This patchset update as comment, and do something as change as below:
1. use sort_key and sort_dir as sort params, keep the same as glance api
2. remove 'required_by_policy' of 'id' from RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP, because 'primary_key' duplicated with it. So add 'primary_key' to 'fields' in 'PaginationHelper.update_fields'."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26:

'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28: (8 inline comments)

Alex-

A few minor items that popped up on the re-read.  I've been thinking a bit about the defaults value for sorts and it shouldn't be a list. Down the road this can lead to accidental value accumulation.  There are two options to fix this: 1) change the default value to a tuple or 2) None.  I like sorts=() since it indicates that the value should be a sequence.  Also since tuples are immutable logic errors will show up quickly.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

Makes sense.  Since you like sorts=None, then let's use that as the default value."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 28.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

patchset 28, fix bug for api_common.SortingEmulatedHelper.update_fields'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28: (4 inline comments)

Mark, thanks for your review!

Is that you mean if someone want to change the sorts value, he must check the value was None or build another tuple that prevent accidental value changing?

But we have many testcase can found the wrong code logic, is right? If we set sorts default value to None or (), developer also can change the sorts to anything by assignment directly.

If we change the sorts default value, I prefer use sorts=None. Because if we use sorts=(), that wasn't enough, we should change api_common.get_sorts return tuple (('key1', True), ('key2', False)). Otherwise, developer will confuse the sorts was list or tuple. If sort is list, developer can modify list directly. If sort is tuple, developer need build another tuple. But we will modify the sorts params in (Pagination/Sorting)Helper, tuple was inconvenience.

Any thought?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Works for me

(9 inline comments)

I have only extremely minor comments.
None of them is a real blocker though, but it would be good if you could have a look at them (especially the fact that the value for PAGINATION_INFINITE is still 'infinite')

If you would like to address some comments, but you feel that it might take too much time, we can merge this patch, and file bugs for addressing them separately, as I think it's functionally complete, and the quality of the code meets the standard we've set for Grizzly.

I have done a good deal of functional testing, and the quality of the code looks great. It's been a tremendous work from Alex.

I cannot swear this patch is bug free, and we are aware that the 'emulated' pagination mode is expensive (just like the emulated bulk). commit_message:
Supporting pagination in api v2.0

Implements bp support-pagination-in-api-v2.0

Add sort and pagination feature for api v2.0.
*Add sort_key, sort_dir for sorting feature.
*Add limit, marker, page_reverse for pagination feature.
*Add emulated sorting and pagination

Native pagination and native sorting implemented for:
*plugins: ovs, linuxbridge
*extensions: l3 securitygroup

Emulated pagination and sorting enabled for:
extensions: lbaas

Change-Id: I28ec6ab7bcae9839cb42c6d60bbfff7250de13ed

commit_message:
Change CIDR column size on migration version 149

As discussed in review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/22238 cidr column needs
up to 43 characters in some cases, and this should be upgrade to avoid data get
lost.

Related to bug-1127696

Change-Id: I35d4565389d03fce86103289cf6447f824efeba0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-11 21:03:11.000000000', 'message': "Provide way to pass rxtx factor to quantum

This patch adds a config option quantum_rxtx_factor which by default is set to
False. When this is set to True it will pass the instance's rxtx_factor to
quantum on port creation. When implementing this I was hoping to do it without
adding another config flag.

In order to do this without a flag we would need nova to query quantum for
which extensions it has running and if running one that desires the
rxtx_factor then pass in that value. The reason I did not implement it this
way is because the query would need to be done everytime from the nova in
allocate_for_instance() to avoid the case of where the extensions change on
the quantum side. Implementing it this way would add an extra RTT between
nova and quantum.

Implemenets blueprint pass-rxtx-factor-to-quantum

Change-Id: I001cfaf348a3f0c8144c0226559752555c486db0
"}, {'created': '2013-02-13 22:12:25.000000000', 'message': "Provide way to pass rxtx factor to quantum

This patch adds a config option quantum_extension_sync which by default is set
to 600 seconds. After 600 seconds the next time nova needs to create a resource
in quantum it will requery quantum for the extensions that it has loaded.

Hopefully in havana something smarter will be implemented rather than using
time sync. I believe a better way to implement this would be to have each
compute host keep a pool of persistant sockets open to quantum for it to
communicate over. Resync'ing then would only happen if the connection to
quantum broke because quantum needs to be restarted in order to change the
extensions it is using

Implemenets blueprint pass-rxtx-factor-to-quantum

Change-Id: I001cfaf348a3f0c8144c0226559752555c486db0
"}, {'created': '2013-02-14 01:38:22.000000000', 'message': "Provide way to pass rxtx factor to quantum

commit_message:
Provide way to pass rxtx factor to quantum

This patch adds a config option quantum_extension_sync_interval which by
default is set to 600 seconds. After 600 seconds the next time nova needs to
create a resource in quantum it will requery quantum for the extensions
that it has loaded.

Hopefully in Havana something smarter will be implemented rather than using
time sync. I believe a better way to implement this would be to have each
compute host keep a pool of persistant sockets open to quantum for it to
communicate over. Resync'ing then would only happen if the connection to
quantum broke because quantum needs to be restarted in order to change the
extensions it is using

Implemenets blueprint pass-rxtx-factor-to-quantum

Change-Id: I001cfaf348a3f0c8144c0226559752555c486db0

commit_message:
Fix syntax error in  cinder-volume-usage-audit

There was a syntax error in a print statement in cinder-volume-usage-audit
which caused the script to crash.

Fixes LP bug #1130266

Change-Id: If4b0102ec5218fc8347f97041ac65f633111c26f

commit_message:
Fix create volume from image.

Fix for bug 1129199

During creating a volume from an image, the volume status changed
from creating to active, skipping the download phase. This bug was most
likely introduced during:
https://review.openstack.org/20514
This patch fixes the issue by change image_location back to image_id at
the correct place.
This patch also fixes an error in the exception handling, and the update
of the volume status after creation.

Change-Id: Ib9b647031c029387b776c27f9233388bd2c67e9c

commit_message:
Add function for listing native threads to eventlet backdoor

The eventlet backdoor has a 'pgt' function for listing green
threads and their stack traces. This adds a new 'pnt' function
for doing the same with native threads.

Change-Id: If6dcfd8dde61c96adfc6e052e5ec7db82914cd55
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-12 16:47:33.000000000', 'message': 'Only wrap the msg in an envelope.

The envelope wrapping should be done around
the message itself, not the ZeroMQ-specific
envelope parts.

Change-Id: Ib04e3d092c9596146f1048d3502ac248496d313b
'}, {'created': '2013-02-12 19:46:33.000000000', 'message': "Better support RPC envelopes in impl_zmq

The ZeroMQ driver includes its own envelopes.
This patch introduce versioning to that
envelope, eliminating the previously reserved
'style' field.

A new iteration of the zeromq-envelope is
introduced, 'impl_zmq_v2'. It specifies
that the zeromq-envelope should be proceeded
by an unpacked array representing key value
pairs of the standard RPC Envelope.

Because the key-values of the RPC Envelope
can be successfully transformed with bytes(),

commit_message:
Support RPC envelopes in impl_zmq

This patch began as a set
of tests verifying the functionality of
sending and receiving RPC envelopes when
using impl_zmq. It was discovered that
when enabled, RPC envelopes were not
actually working,

The ZeroMQ driver includes its own envelopes.
This patch introduce versioning to that
envelope, eliminating the previously reserved
'style' field.

A new iteration of the zeromq-envelope is
introduced, 'impl_zmq_v2'. It specifies
that the zeromq-envelope should be followed
by an unpacked array representing key value
pairs of the standard RPC Envelope.

Because the key-values of the RPC Envelope
can be successfully transformed with bytes(),
this prevents the need to double-serialize
the content traversing the message bus.

Also removes some unused imports.

Closes bug 1123709
Closes bug 1055446

Change-Id: Ib04e3d092c9596146f1048d3502ac248496d313b

commit_message:
Update Storwize/SVC driver for Grizzly.

Includes FC support, create_cloned_volume, volume type support,
get_volume_stats, and minor bug fixes.

Change-Id: I13e3d7921c5127e6b4e0cbb4e91761e0249ec295

[{'created': '2013-02-18 16:01:46.000000000', 'message': 'Create connection for each qpid notification.

Previously the qpid notifier created a connection to the qpid broker
when the notifier was initialized and reused that for each notification.
This is broken when API workers are used.  Instead, just create a new
connection on demand when a notification gets sent out.

Change-Id: I7a17e5e4bd8efd771ff8cd0e1d04107a79789763
'}, {'created': '2013-02-18 16:03:03.000000000', 'message': 'Create connection for each qpid notification.

Previously the qpid notifier created a connection to the qpid broker
when the notifier was initialized and reused that for each notification.
This is broken when API workers are used.  Instead, just create a new
connection on demand when a notification gets sent out.

Fix bug 1100317.

Change-Id: I7a17e5e4bd8efd771ff8cd0e1d04107a79789763

commit_message:
Create connection for each qpid notification.

Previously the qpid notifier created a connection to the qpid broker
when the notifier was initialized and reused that for each notification.
This is broken when API workers are used.  Instead, just create a new
connection on demand when a notification gets sent out.

Fix bug 1100317.

Change-Id: I7a17e5e4bd8efd771ff8cd0e1d04107a79789763

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-19 21:40:34.000000000', 'message': 'Allow MultiConfigParser get from mutliple sections

MultiConfigParser.get() takes a section name and a list of option names.

In order to support aliases of options which span multiple groups, we
need to be able to look up from multiple sections. We can easily do this
by changing MultiConfigParser.get() to take a list of (section, name)
tuples.

Change-Id: I50656c021669ccb947ceb56dfcf37d3fffcba194
'}]
commit_message:
Allow MultiConfigParser get from mutliple sections

MultiConfigParser.get() takes a section name and a list of option names.

In order to support aliases of options which span multiple groups, we
need to be able to look up from multiple sections. We can easily do this
by changing MultiConfigParser.get() to take a list of (section, name)
tuples.

Change-Id: I50656c021669ccb947ceb56dfcf37d3fffcba194

We have two copies of this method with the only difference being the
use of the multi kwarg. Obviously, it makes sense to combine the two.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-19 18:20:36.000000000', 'message': 'heat engine : avoid returning empty resource error strings

Avoid the possibility of returning an empty string (when Exceptions
have not got a string message), or parser.py will treat the error
as success and the resource operation failure will not be correctly
reflected in the resource state.

fixes bug 1130270

Change-Id: I1c55dea1f9615cd4b037802ff8c1066694bffea6
'}]
commit_message:
heat engine : avoid returning empty resource error strings

Avoid the possibility of returning an empty string (when Exceptions
have not got a string message), or parser.py will treat the error
as success and the resource operation failure will not be correctly
reflected in the resource state.

fixes bug 1130270

Change-Id: I1c55dea1f9615cd4b037802ff8c1066694bffea6

commit_message:
XenAPINFS: fix capacity reporting

Fixes bug 1129056

XenAPINFS did not implement the get_volume_stats method, thus
CapacityFilter fitered out the host, thus no volume was scheduled. This
fix is working around this problem quickly, by reporting an 'unknown'
capacity.

Change-Id: I1dc5327e420a3316201318d52f602ced071d459b

commit_message:
Stub additional FloatingIP methods in FlatManager

Fixes bug #989746.

Added some stub methods for floating ip allocation in FlatManager in
order to prevent exceptions from being raised when they are called.

Changed get_floating_ip_by_address() in FlatManager to return a dict
with expected keys for a floating ip, rather than None.

Updated patch from Andrew Laski and added unit tests.

Change-Id: I4ee1f5cf986b6f3411605aae5c1bc4e8cc2377b1

commit_message:
Assign unique names with os-multiple-create.

This patch introduces a new configuration option,
multi_instance_display_name_template, which makes
it so that all instances are given a unique
display_name and hostname when requesting that
multiple instances get created at the same time.

Implements bp multi-boot-instance-naming

DocImpact

Change-Id: Id8e7dac1adadbb101dd1027807867ab13d3b7e80

[{'created': '2013-02-14 10:08:36.000000000', 'message': 'Implement name space for domains

Creates a separate name space for each domain for the name attribute of
user, groups and projects - meaning that the names of the entities
only have to be unique within that domain.

Implementation of this within the SQL backends is handled by simply
changing the uniqueness constraints on the relevant attributes.  KVS
and LDAP backends do not yet support domain separation (blocked by
existing restrictions, already raised as bugs).

An issue exists for the downward migration with this change in that
if the database has used and populated with the name space in place
then the downward migration may fail due to clashing names when you
try and revert to a global name space (raised as a separte bug)

This patch also improves the group support in the KVS backend and
cleans up string quoting in the 016 migration fucntions

commit_message:
Implement name space for domains

Creates a separate name space for each domain for the name attribute of
user, groups and projects - meaning that the names of these entities
only have to be unique within that domain.

Implementation of this within the SQL backends is handled by simply
changing the uniqueness constraints on the relevant attributes.  KVS
and LDAP backends do not yet support domain separation (blocked by
existing restrictions, already raised as bugs).

An issue exists for the downward migration with this change in that
if the database has been used and populated with the name space in place
then the downward migration may fail due to clashing names when you
try and revert to a global name space (raised as a separate bug)

This patch also improves the group support in the KVS backend and
cleans up string quoting in the 016 migration fucntions, and fixes an
issue where the SQL update_project was not updating a change in domain_id.

Change-Id: I8f0df0e1bf84bfd26b8ef5505fe5fafd930dc78b

commit_message:
Use proper setup bits in python-heatclient

Import latest oslo bits for setup

Use a default version of 2013.1

Change-Id: I704cb4040679b51c230e8f1d598857b9bf3f87c2

[{'created': '2013-02-19 15:00:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Nova modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282.

Change-Id: Ib90d6379320ff1d007f8a661f7ddaa286ba6918e
'}]
commit_message:
Add a safe_minidom_parse_string function.

Adds a new utils.safe_minidom_parse_string function and
updates external API facing Nova modules to use it.
This ensures we have safe defaults on our incoming API XML parsing.

Internally safe_minidom_parse_string uses a ProtectedExpatParser
class to disable DTDs and entities from being parsed when using
minidom.

Fixes LP Bug #1100282.

Change-Id: Ib90d6379320ff1d007f8a661f7ddaa286ba6918e

commit_message:
Use oslo-config-2013.1b3

The cfg API is now available via the oslo-config library, so switch to
it and remove the copied-and-pasted version.

Removes the load of copied-and-pasted cfg from each application
in authtoken middleware.
Depends on oslo-config deployments:
Nova I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc
Glance I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc
Quantum I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc
Cinder I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc

Add the 2013.1b3 tarball to tools/pip-requires - this will be changed
to 'oslo-config>=2013.1' when oslo-config is published to pypi. This
will happen in time for grizzly final.

Change-Id: I18c450174277c8e2d15ed93879da6cd92074c27a

[{'created': '2013-02-19 13:31:37.000000000', 'message': "Remove old, outdated keystone devref docs

The doc/source/old directory contained several docs
that were marked as 'old' and hadn't been updated for more
than a year.

This patch simply removes them - they aren't referred to in
any way noticable on keystone.openstack.org.

Change-Id: Ida57e0321be09aa8ddcb966f386132946017cdcb
"}]
commit_message:
Remove old, outdated keystone devref docs

The doc/source/old directory contained several docs
that were marked as 'old' and hadn't been updated for more
than a year.

This patch simply removes them - they aren't referred to in
any way noticable on keystone.openstack.org.

Change-Id: Ida57e0321be09aa8ddcb966f386132946017cdcb

commit_message:
Use oslo-config-2013.1b3

The cfg API is now available via the oslo-config library, so switch to
it and remove the copied-and-pasted version.

Add the 2013.1b3 tarball to tools/pip-requires - this will be changed
to 'oslo-config>=2013.1' when oslo-config is published to pypi. This
will happen in time for grizzly final.

Remove the 'deps = pep8==1.3.3' from tox.ini as it means all the other
deps get installed with easy_install which can't install oslo-config
from the URL.

Change-Id: I4815aeb8a9341a31a250e920157f15ee15cfc5bc

[{'created': '2013-01-30 17:09:27.000000000', 'message': "Implements token expiration handling

This implements handling of token expiration. Once the token is expired,
this will request automatically for a new one.

A special case is introduced if the user specified a token when the client
is initialized: this is the auth_token_from_user. In this case, we can't
know the expiration date, so we just assume it will never expire and don't
handle it ourself.

commit_message:
Implements token expiration handling

This implements handling of token expiration. Once the token is expired,
this will request automatically for a new one.

A special case is introduced if the user specified a token when the client
is initialized: this is the auth_token_from_user. In this case, we can't
know the expiration date, so we just assume it will never expire and don't
handle it ourself.

Change-Id: I3771ff5d669da015d4aa259de422c5d81aed3eb4
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Adding network-topology view for quantum

Implements bp quantum-network-topology

- network-topology pane shows the topology of quantum network
- supports network, router , instances now
- support of load balancer is future work

Change-Id: Idb1bf2d3add43cf51ed23ebaac3ee740b03498aa

commit_message:
Exit if DHCP agent interface_driver is not defined

Fixes bug 1130052

In addition to this:
Uses "raise  SystemExit()" instaed of the exit for the L3
agent.

Change-Id: I8130745c9de62619189e158944fa9e4ed25be774

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-19 17:20:33.000000000', 'message': "Enhance IPAdresses migration tests

This enhances IPAddresses tests to check if the migration goes fine with longer
IPv6, and with ipv6 that can be shortened (postgresql uses shortened form,
mysql and sqlite doesn't).

Also enhances cidr tests to check migration of shortenables cidrs, and cidrs
that postgresql suppress its prefix, like 10.0.0.0/32 cause it is pretty much
the same as 10.0.0.0

Partially implements bp migration-testing-with-data

Change-Id: Ie5296a020ef8311c4e2630700d7a464afba9ea28
"}]
commit_message:
Enhance IPAdresses migration tests

This enhances IPAddresses tests to check if the migration goes fine with longer
IPv6, and with ipv6 that can be shortened (postgresql uses shortened form,
mysql and sqlite doesn't).

Also enhances cidr tests to check migration of shortenables cidrs, and cidrs
that postgresql suppress its prefix, like 10.0.0.0/32 cause it is pretty much
the same as 10.0.0.0

Partially implements bp migration-testing-with-data

Change-Id: Ie5296a020ef8311c4e2630700d7a464afba9ea28

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21243/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/724 : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-02-06 04:42:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Code looks great. Can you also add a import_group method or should this come in another patch?'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-02-06 15:16:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark,

Would it make sense to add an option to import all options from a specific module?

CONF.import_all_opt('source.module')

thanks,
dims"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-02-06 15:53:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmm, it might ... but there's actually no way of knowing which options are registered by importing a module, especially given that the module may already have been imported previously

[{'created': '2013-02-05 19:43:09.000000000', 'message': "Add ConfigFilter wrapper class

Implements blueprint cfg-filter-view

At the moment, if a module requires a configuration option from another
module, we do:

  CONF.import_opt('source.module', 'option_name')

but, in fact, all options from the imported module are available for
use.

The new ConfigFilter class makes it possible to enforce which options
are available within a module e.g. with

  CONF = cfgfilter.ConfigFilter(cfg.CONF)
  CONF.import_opt('foo', 'source.module')
  CONF.register_opt(StrOpt('bar'))

then the foo and bar options would be the only options available via
this CONF object while still being available via the global cfg.CONF
object.

Change-Id: Ie3aa2cd090a626da8afd27ecb78853cbf279bc8b
"}, {'created': '2013-02-09 19:43:43.000000000', 'message': "Add ConfigFilter wrapper class

commit_message:
Add ConfigFilter wrapper class

Implements blueprint cfg-filter-view

At the moment, if a module requires a configuration option from another
module, we do:

  CONF.import_opt('source.module', 'option_name')

but, in fact, all options from the imported module are available for
use.

The new ConfigFilter class makes it possible to enforce which options
are available within a module e.g. with

  CONF = cfgfilter.ConfigFilter(cfg.CONF)
  CONF.import_opt('foo', 'source.module')
  CONF.register_opt(StrOpt('bar'))

then the foo and bar options would be the only options available via
this CONF object while still being available via the global cfg.CONF
object.

Change-Id: Ie3aa2cd090a626da8afd27ecb78853cbf279bc8b

commit_message:
heat engine : Implement rollback for stack create

Implement stack rollback for create_stack, so if a stack
creation fails we automatically rollback (ie delete) the
stack

NOTE : this option defaults to on, so use the --disable-rollback
option to the CLI tools if you want to disable this feature

blueprint stack-rollback

Change-Id: I70a3822426706d0787e571517e059baff1406c0f

[{'created': '2013-02-18 15:05:23.000000000', 'message': "heat engine : Only create periodic task on CREATE_COMPLETE

Only create the stack periodic watcher task if the stack create
completed successfully, since we don't want a watcher task if
the stack ended up rolling back (or just in CREATE_FAILED state)

commit_message:
heat engine : Only create periodic task on CREATE_COMPLETE

Only create the stack periodic watcher task if the stack create
completed successfully, since we don't want a watcher task if
the stack ended up rolling back (or just in CREATE_FAILED state)

Change-Id: I5592fa106f740eb2e1dcf40e98a2656627715b6f

commit_message:
Modify dhcp agent for agent management extension

2nd part of blueprint quantum-scheduler

Remove openstack openstack listener on DHCP agent side.
Add DHCPagent notifier on quantum server side.

Change-Id: I196691650a99ba865bf06081a1fc4546f9fac7bd

commit_message:
Match other python-*client prettytable dependency

The other openstack clients use prettytable>=0.6,<0.7. For several
reasons (primarily a lack of support in pip), we will match that here.

Change-Id: Id4fb08ae48a65666014c96a22baefe46a771b002

This patch adds unit test for ryu-agent.
Also, add the lacking test for the default configuration value.

commit_message:
Install rtslib when installing cinder

It doesnt make sense to put rtslib in tools/test-requires
since it is not directly using the python module while running
the tests, since the tests use cinder-rtstool.

Change-Id: Ib39b91e25f22b4943ef17eee50967828f7460b25
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Swallow UserWarning from glance-cache-manage

Fixes bug 1129445

Previously, we exposed internal technical debt as an apparent
user-facing warning.

Now the warning is swallowed in the internal case, but continues
to be seen by external users of this library.

Change-Id: I6d6e95f762b81bb53836cade9ba698a679ac1c5e

commit_message:
adding v2 support to cinderclient

This will allow the cinderclient to speak to the v2 rest api if it's
enabled in the cinder config. Includes additional v2 tests as well.

blueprint cinderclient-v2-support

Change-Id: I004134d9f528a6eadefdaa89eb48087bcae2691f

commit_message:
Metadata support for NVP plugin

Bug #1121119

Allows the NVP plugin to leverage the metadata proxy, by creating an
ad-hoc topology for allowing access to a metadata proxy from a NVP
router leveraging existing agents.

This patch also removes previous code for metadata support in the
NVP plugin, which was based on DHCP Option 121. This is now provided
by the dhcp agent as well.

Change-Id: If37ef388e063f40bb06908ee2f72c431f29dac31

commit_message:
make stack_delete_after decorator tolerate deleted stacks

Make the stack_delete_after decorator try/except so it doesn't cause a
test failure if the test has already done a delete during the test

Change-Id: I4a5e096478ece0de02cc910366a5d361d5ee45e0

commit_message:
Fix _get_instance_volume_block_device_info call parameter

_get_instance_volume_block_device_info() is expecting an
instance dict-like object instead of instance_uuid

Fix bug 1129441

Change-Id: Id4d536553ce9858434c377653fa79562e1282a34

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-18 20:56:17.000000000', 'message': "create new cidr type for data storage

it turns out that the 149 migration was overly agressive in it's
IPAddress conversion, as we actually have a few columns that are
really CIDR values. This means that 39 chars isn't enough space to
store even a normalized IPv6 cidr in the worst case (you need 4
more to support /127).

We must also normalize IPv6 address cidrs otherwise 43 chars isn't
long enough. This was more of a problem in theory, than in practice,
as real IPv6 addresses rarely are non compressible.

This adds a migration to bump up the CIDR columns to 43 characters.
There is an infinitessimal chance that someone using mysql and long
IPv6 values might loose data in 149 because of truncation. This
doesn't address that, which would require modifying 149.

Change-Id: I54539ac9c257d726bc4db5943169b5284cc847d3

commit_message:
create new cidr type for data storage

it turns out that the 149 migration was overly agressive in its
IPAddress conversion, as we actually have a few columns that are
really CIDR values. This means that 39 chars isn't enough space to
store even a normalized IPv6 cidr in the worst case (you need 4
more to support /127).

We must also normalize IPv6 address cidrs otherwise 43 chars isn't
long enough. This was more of a problem in theory, than in practice,
as real IPv6 addresses rarely are non compressible.

This adds a migration to bump up the CIDR columns to 43 characters.
There is an infinitessimal chance that someone using mysql and long
IPv6 values might loose data in 149 because of truncation. This
doesn't address that, which would require modifying 149.

The native pg CIDR column type is not used because it would require
additional scrubbing of the data as CIDR is invalid if any host bits
are set (and it will fail on type conversion).

Fixes bug #1127696

Change-Id: I54539ac9c257d726bc4db5943169b5284cc847d3

commit_message:
Live migration with an auto selection of dest

Add ability to let scheduler decide on target host during live migration.

Implements: blueprint live-migration-scheduling
Change-Id: Id596fa3a0ef2b1b5faf854e4b4557b3c4b413e39

commit_message:
Add select_hosts to scheduler manager rpc

This adds a select_hosts(...) method to the scheduler manager
rpc that allows other services to query it for the best suited
host instead of relying on it to proxy its messages.

This can be used by extensions that need the scheduler to determine
the best-fit host but want to prepare and send their own messages
to that host.

Change-Id: I5b4760114dfcdb0464fac8ea81f46f7532ac0580

commit_message:
Add an update option to run_tests.sh

This commit adds an update option to run_tests.sh. This option
is used to rerun install_venv.py on an already installed venv.
This will then just update out of date packages with pip.

Change-Id: I808f019de688387b14bc7a43eea4e45b05948e6b

commit_message:
Do not use abbreviated config group names (zookeeper)

Using abbreviated config group names just makes the config file harder
to understand, so just use full name.

zk => zookeeper

Change-Id: Ia8b3ff9201365477003535600e419540deae7341

(4 inline comments)

First - it is great that we are getting rid of that User-Project-Memebership table!!!!  However, a couple of things:

1) If we are going to use the special members' role...do we not have to prevent someone explicitly deleting it, in the same way we do the DEFAULT_DOMAIN_ID?

2) I just wonder whether there is a totally different way of achieving this whole change, namely providing a new implementation of get_projects_for_user() and get_project_users(), e.g.:

def get_project_users():
    return all users that have a role on this project or who have it specified as their default_project

def get_projects_for_user():
    return  all projects the user has a role on plus their default_project (if they have one)

Obviously each of the above would be two DB lookups"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-11 16:55:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
project membership to role conversion

Changes the relationship between users and projects.
There is no more direct membership in projects.  Instead,
all membership is now done via roles.
A default role has been created called _member_ with a uuid (both
configurable) that will be added in place of the group membership
for databse upgrades.

DocImpact:  https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1087483

Change-Id: I2482f9ef7b838e5dade5096d6d00e81db71604d1

'}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2013-01-24 21:50:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The proposer of this patch has clearly not tested it.

Requests 1.0 changed the API significantly in backwards incompatible ways. Until keystoneclient is updated to either support >1.0 or support both versions, it is incompatible with requests >1.0."}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2013-01-24 22:20:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

On further investigation, it looks like I'm wrong. keystoneclient doesn't appear to be using any of the stuff that changed in requests, and the tests pass with the new lib, so I guess it does look like it's working.

I'm still a bit worried because the tempest gate did not run with requests 1.1.0, but instead uninstalled that and used the lower version from the nova requirement.

packages needing it, so remove this upper limitation.

Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Remove <1.0 limitation on requests

There seems to be no reason to limit to an upper version, and that blocks
packages needing it, so remove this upper limitation.

Change-Id: I24c0ead32a8884ed97484c315228a0544c617d71
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-08 18:01:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes a race condition on updating security group rules during
instance creation

During creating the instance, compute manager makes an rpc call
to "allocate_for_instance" from the network manager, which will
in turn end up making a rpc cast to each compute_manager with
an instance in the group(s) than need to be refreshed calling
refresh_instance_security_rules.

When an instance is being created is in a group that has a
rule referring to itself, that chain will end up trying to
refresh the rules for the instance which is still being created.

That call will find its way down to do_refresh_instance_rules()
in libvirt/firewall - which will in turn try to get network_info
from the global "network_infos" in firewall.

But the entry in network_infos for this instance might not of
been added yet, as that only happens when the create of the
instance calls "prepare_instance_filter which comes later in
the sequence as part of driver.spawn

The fix here adds a synchronisation lock to the incomming
refresh call so that it is blocked until any in-progress
thread on the instance is finished.

Change-Id: I550e286aa4777b011633550109e18e03d63a4bbb
'}, {'created': '2013-02-08 19:32:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes a race condition on updating security group rules

That call will find its way down to do_refresh_instance_rules()
in libvirt/firewall - which will in turn try to get network_info
from the global "network_infos" in firewall.

But the entry in network_infos for this instance might not of
been added yet, as that only happens when the create of the
instance calls "prepare_instance_filter which comes later in
the sequence as part of driver.spawn

The fix here adds a synchronisation lock to the incomming
refresh call so that it is blocked until any in-progress
thread on the instance is finished.

Change-Id: I550e286aa4777b011633550109e18e03d63a4bbb
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes a race condition on updating security group rules

During creating the instance, compute manager makes an rpc call
to "allocate_for_instance" from the network manager, which will
in turn end up making a rpc cast to each compute_manager with
an instance in the group(s) than need to be refreshed calling
refresh_instance_security_rules.

When an instance is being created is in a group that has a
rule referring to itself, that chain will end up trying to
refresh the rules for the instance which is still being created.

That call will find its way down to do_refresh_instance_rules()
in libvirt/firewall - which will in turn try to get network_info
from the global "network_infos" in firewall.

But the entry in network_infos for this instance might not of
been added yet, as that only happens when the create of the
instance calls "prepare_instance_filter which comes later in
the sequence as part of driver.spawn

The fix here adds a synchronisation lock to the incomming
refresh call so that it is blocked until any in-progress
thread on the instance is finished.

Change-Id: I550e286aa4777b011633550109e18e03d63a4bbb

directory path in the case ELEMENTS_DIR was not set.

This change raises an error in this situation, so that
element-info does not silently fail.

Change-Id: Iec50f934feb13dfed64d69297a3af6ac9f842677

commit_message:
Prevent silent failure of element-info:

bin/element-info accesses it's library via a symlink:
  bin/diskimage_builder -> diskimage_builder

This causes the relative path in elements.py to be
incorrect.

element-info silently fails in this situation, because
it allows missing 'element-deps' files, so that these files
may be optional.

This change causes element-info to fail explicitly if $ELEMENTS_DIR
is not set, as it now is when called by diskimage-create, and
adds tests reflecting this behavior.

Change-Id: Iec50f934feb13dfed64d69297a3af6ac9f842677

"}, {'created': '2013-02-18 20:25:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix hacking tests on osx

There were a few incompatibilities with the hacking tests and
OSX. Readlink -f doesn't work so use cd and pwd instead. Importing
a module with path separators doesn't work, so recursively import
the module. Finally the extra / in the find command was not needed.

Add a 'set -e' to run_pep8 to make sure test fails on any error

Ignore paste as it doesn't have an __init__ in its top level directory

Change-Id: Ifc66da7b872faa08f3be98f8b10486181ba77861
"}]
commit_message:
Fix hacking tests on osx

There were a few incompatibilities with the hacking tests and
OSX. Readlink -f doesn't work so use cd and pwd instead. Importing
a module with path separators doesn't work, so recursively import
the module. Finally the extra / in the find command was not needed.

Add a 'set -e' to run_pep8 to make sure test fails on any error

Ignore paste as it doesn't have an __init__ in its top level directory

Change-Id: Ifc66da7b872faa08f3be98f8b10486181ba77861

commit_message:
Add an update option to run_tests.sh

This commit adds an update option to run_tests.sh. This option
is used to rerun install_venv.py on an already installed venv.
This will then just update out of date packages with pip.

Change-Id: I8a0a8ba5a9015950bc271f11cbc77308d993fde3

commit_message:
remove SimpleScheduler from docs

fixes bug 1121819

SimpleScheduler was deprecated in Folsom and has been removed in
 Grizzly. This patch removes the content, and updates examples to
current defaults.

Change-Id: I44d0021bfd0eecfe09b23b6bb5d2dcfe1ac63f3f

commit_message:
Add and check data functions for test_migrations 141

Before the 141 migration test is run, _prerun_141 populates the migrations
table with a generated uuid. The _check_141 function checks that
the uuid migrated properly down to 36 char.

Partially implements: blueprint migration-testing-with-data

Change-Id: I43b47f69a94720bf9487eb30576035493700ddca

Add image to request_spec during resize

Resolves bug 1117882.

commit_message:
Make sure to install the oslo package as well.

Each package under a namespace that should install that namespace
package so the __init__.py for the namespace gets copied.

Fixes Bug 1129587

Change-Id: I064b05479c8a41d8f793886d2a5895dce166a85a

'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-16 16:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

I have decided to make relatively small change with a huge benefit and resubmit.  In this version of the change, I redefined msg_id to be the thing that uniquely identifies the message and have it returned by the caller.  In the old model, msg_id identified the queue upon which to send the reply.  Although I feel it is confusing for msg_id to be the name for the queue, I think it best to keep the meaning in the new version.  The reason is when an uplevel caller calls a downlevel callee if it uplevel caller has a single reply queue named by msg_id as in the prior model, at least it can detect that it received a reply that was from a downlevel callee (e.g. the reply_id is missing from the reply).  This will allow an error message to be thrown so the user knows why the RPC failed.  In this review version, the reply is lost since the single reply queue is named by the new reply_id variable.

One other thing I could add for the above scenario is a check on the number of waiters.  If there is only one waiter (e.g no concurrency), then there is no problem in routing the message to the calling greenthread.  A error message should still be posted, but the RPC could be allowed to succeed.  If there is any concurrency (e.g more than one call waiter), there is no way to route the reply, so it would have to be allowed to fail by giving an error message, throwing away the reply and letting the waiting caller time out.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-16 23:21:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-16 23:24:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

I added a comment to try to find a solution for managing an null reply_id, please let me know what do you think.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-18 17:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

(1 inline comment)

My only concern is about the backward compatibility which seems to be hard to have.
This is a point we need to keep in mind as long as someone is enabling this new feature, all "actors" must run the same code. That's easy to achieve in a brand new installation and a bit more complicated in updating an existing installation.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-21 16:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Another thought regarding compatibility: It would be easy enough to apply this patch to Folsom (or any and all prior levels). If the default for Folsom were disabled and the default for Grizzly were enabled, the upgrade path would be to apply the latest patches for the downlevel version before migrating and all would work.  Note that the code detects an uplevel RPC call and responds appropriately regardless if the fast feature is enabled or not.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:37:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-22 15:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Added thoughts on how to make this simultaneously forward and backward compatible without having to make it a strict toggle.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-22 17:53:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Elaborating more on compat.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-22 18:07:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Changing to a -1 because I think we can do this without breaking compat (deprecating old methodology and removing after one release)"}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-23 03:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

I propose that we simply change amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue to default to False.  Then it is downlevel compatible by default and those wishing for a performance improvement will have to live without downlevel compatiblity.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-23 03:22:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Could you explicitly close the queue once the local consumer has gone away? Is this because durable_queues is enabled?

My concern is that by default, it should be backwards compatible by default (i.e. amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue = False), but that if that value is False, then the old behavior may not be safely removed in the H release. Unless, perhaps, in H it was set to True, and finally in the I-release the old code-path was removed in full.

A backwards-compatible version would NOT be faster. In fact, it would be slower. However, the idea would be that you could disable the backwards-compatibility for the performance boost that you're seeking. Then, backwards compatibility would be removed entirely in H.

Also, what do you think of keeping msg_id with its current value (which is really a reply id already) and adding 'reply_channel' for the new queue?"}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-01-23 12:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: No score

(1 inline comment)

Please see at my inline comment'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-23 16:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

Eric, I think you are missing something about the compatibility of this patch set.  Here is a summary:  New->New=Pass, Old->New=Pass, New->Old=RPC completed on the backend, error message regarding compatibility in logs, rpc timeout.  The significance is old->new works.  A new callee can detect an old caller by not receiving the reply_id and respond in the old way.  This means in the H release we can remove the old code and option (unless we are worried about upgrading from an E or earlier releases).  I have mentioned an alternative is to apply this patch to A, B, C, D, E and F releases and require the latest patches to those releases before migrating to anything G and above.  If we do that, we can take out the enable/disable option in G, assuming it gets in G.  So, we have at least two options.  (1) Leave in the enable/disable option with a default of disabled and remove the old code in the H release.  (2) Change all earlier releases to have this fix with the option disabled by default and remove the old code in this (G) release.... Regarding the reply_channel idea.  I'm not clear on what you are suggesting.  I don't like msg_id being the thing that identifies the queue but that is legacy code and keeping it that way is the only way to get the new->old to be able to identify the old callee and log an error message to help the user identify why things are not working.  Also, "channel" is an AMQP term that is different from what you suggest we use it for (reply_channel == queue name).  That is, if I understand what an AMQP channel really is, which I think is the equivalnt of a socket connection.  I hope this makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-23 16:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Just to be clear, my compatibility summary in the prior comment are with qmqp_rpc_single_reply_queue disabled.  When enabled, all variations work.  New->New, New->Old, Old->New.  And regardless of the option setting on either side of the RPC, New->New always works.  With patch set 9.  At minimum, I need to change the default to False and resubmit for review, but want you comments on the previous comment first.'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-01-23 16:47:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

just a request for clarification.
Thanks'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-23 16:57:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I do understand what disabling amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue provides.

Why is there no reply queue leak prior to this patch? Granted, closing the queue might be more complex, but it can still be done.

The idea behind switching msg_id and reply_id is because of what these mean in an abstracted sense and how a legacy message recipient interprets that message. This is to say, in the case of messages from New->Old.

The old msg_id is the topic to which call() responses are sent by old clients. This is ALSO a reply identifier in version<=Folsom since that topic only ever receives a single message. The fact that in older releases msg_id correlated to a topic is irrelevant to the fact it is ALSO a reply-identifier. Your patch is suggesting that msg_id becomes strictly a topic and NOT a reply-identifier as it is at present. That affects the compatibility with older clients (assuming the rest of the code is made compatible) and changes the definition of the context struct.

If instead of adding a key for 'reply-id', you made a key for 'reply-topic' (or '-channel' or whatever terminology is sufficient), then the topic used by new code could be based on this, rather than msg_id.  This matches the behavior of the older clients. They'll send messages back to the newer code and the newer code, if it can still pick up those messages off the old-convention queue, will be able to consume it and join it to the waiting caller.

Sending messages will need to be changed a tad bit in the new code if msg_id is no longer perceived as a topic, but unlike the compatible waiting function, it has marginal performance impact.  Basically, the code to send a reply in new code would be something like:

def msg_reply(conf, msg_id, reply_topic, connection_pool, reply=None,
              failure=None, ending=False, log_failure=True):
    """Sends a reply or an error on the channel signified by msg_id.

    Failure should be a sys.exc_info() tuple.

    """
    with ConnectionContext(conf, connection_pool) as conn:
        if failure:
            failure = rpc_common.serialize_remote_exception(failure,
                                                            log_failure)

        try:
            msg = {'result': reply, 'failure': failure}
        except TypeError:
            msg = {'result': dict((k, repr(v))
                   for k, v in reply.__dict__.iteritems()),
                   'failure': failure}
        if ending:
            msg['ending'] = True
        # If a reply_id exists, add it to the reply
        # otherwise it is a downlevel caller so will not expect it
        if reply_topic:
            topic = reply_topic
            msg['_reply_topic'] = reply_topic
        else:
            topic = msg_id
        conn.direct_send(topic, rpc_common.serialize_msg(msg))'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-23 21:42:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

The reply queue leak is in reference to using the existing implementation in impl_kombu.py of the TopicConsumer for the RPC reply.  There is no leak today, because the existing implementation uses DirectConsumer, which defines the exchanges and queues as "auto_delete".  I was confused when I used the term "durable", sorry about that.

I totally agree with you that using msg_id as the name of the queue upon which to send the response is bad. I even originally submitted this for code for review more like you would like it. See patch set 4 and my comment for that patch. I changed my mind after realizing I could detect the New->Old situation with msg_id identifying the queue in both old and new.  The benefit for that is huge in my mind: being able to tell the customer why something failed. In the prior change, when the option was disabled, there was compatibility for both New->Old and Old->New, as it is in this patch set.  The difference is that with the option enabled, this patch set can detect the failure of New->Old.  Perhaps that isn't as big a deal as I think, but I would like input from more people if you still don't agree with me.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-24 05:15:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

First, just want to check if anyone is still recommending simultaneously waiting on the old MulticallWaiter and the new MulticallProxyWaiter.  In the case that the fast path is disabled, the request will only be sent out in the old way, so it will never come back in the new way and a double wait is not necessary.  In the case of the fast path enabled, doing the double wait would cancel the performance benefit.

Second, there are probably multiple ways to gain an intuitive name for the key that identifies the return queue name (e.g. reply_q) and be able to detect a New->Old situation with the fast path is enabled.  One I toyed with was to change the 'method' key to 'methodv2'.  It just so happens that the old code fails the call and returns the original message when the 'method' key is not found.  The nice thing about that is the new code could detect the error and reissue the request in the old way.  That would provide 100% compatibility at the cost of changing the wire level protocol.  I don't think it is worth the effort.  I see fast path enabled and New->Old as a user error, but one that the user should get a log for.

Another even less attractive idea to me is to send the reply queue in two keys: the old msg_id and a new reply_q.  The message identifier could be sent in a meaningfully named msg_id_v2.  At some future release when the likelihood of an old style installation existing is low, we could remove the old msg_id."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-24 05:28:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I should note that right now, the message that goes over the bus is compatible between ZeroMQ and the AMQP code. They both use a msg_id in a fairly similar way. Even though the messages can't really pass between them, there might be some intrinsic value of having (near?) identical message contents when it comes to tooling, debugging/diagnosis, etc.

Changing 'method' in particular is dangerous because this is actually passed to RPC. That would be a change to the abstraction itself.

My understanding of the code is that the old msg_id can be kept as it is without creating a new msg_id_v2 key.  The use of that key would differ, resulting in different behavior depending on whether or not the reply_q key was present in the message."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-24 16:40:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I don't know where to put this thought, so it's going here.

In general, versioning of the various layers of RPC seems to be a problem.  Initially the API level was versioned and provided for the services that use RPC.  The version-rpc-messages blueprint adds an overall RPC version envelope.  Sadly that leaves out versioning of the specific implementations like RabbitMQ, Qpid and ZMQ.  And none of these versioning blueprints addresses the potential to back off to prior version compatibility.  Maybe we need some sort of capabilities header in the message.  I am not a thought leader in this area, but the problem does seem solvable.  Maybe a new blueprint.  Maybe this is related to the rpc-version-control blueprint, but the back off idea seems to be a bit more."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-24 18:27:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I also don't like the ideas of changing key names in the message.  I just wanted to throw them out there to see if you agreed.  I think we can distill the remaining issue to how to handle msg_id.  Here are the trade offs between the two approaches:

1) Use msg_id as a true unique identifier of the message.

Plus: Wire level compatibility in the meaning of msg_id both with older versions of AMQP based RPC as well as with ZMQ based RPC.

Minus: Not being able to detect New->Old (with fast enabled).  The RPC gets executed, the response is lost and the RPC has to timeout.  The user is not informed of why.

2) Use msg_id as the identifier of the queue in which to respond

Plus: Ability to detect New->Old (wth fast enabled).  The RPC gets executed, the response is received, but not returned to the caller, an error is logged, the RPC has to timeout.

Minus: Is not wire level compatible.

Hm, thinking hard on this, perhaps another Grizzly blueprint could be written to augment Russel Bryant's version-rpc-messages envelope idea to enabled it by default.  Today it is disabled with a TODO to enable it after Grizzly.  With this make the necessary changes to detect an RPC failure caused by New->Old and reissue the RPC without the envelope.  Then make my blueprint dependent upon that one.

And (optionally) perhaps even make a change in the checking of the envelope to look for unexpected content in that envelope.  For example, if we decide in the future to add an implementation version or whatever, that a version that supported the envelope, but not the new content would fail the RPC.

If we were to agree upon that, I think I would be happy with leaving msg_id as the unique identifier.  The biggest advantage being that if worked, it would 100% compatible and the only performance hit would be New->Old, which is acceptable."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-24 18:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I am also thinking that there might be some value in putting this into the envelope. However, I'm not yet certain that the envelope format shouldn't change per requirements of the trusted-messaging blueprint.

In the case of #1, the "new" system could still listen on the old queue at the cost of performance.  Performance gains would be seen by disabling the backwards compatibility, in which case the request is processed, returned, but not joined to the caller, and RPC times out.  Yes, you need to figure out how to close the queues if it isn't straightforward.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-24 18:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I'll try to take a look at the trusted-messaging blueprint.

Regarding case #1 comment, I keep forgetting to make it clear that most of my comments assume amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue is enabled.  If amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue is disabled, the "new" system does in fact only listen on the old queue.  That is the way it works with this patch set.  My whole point of contention is when amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue is enabled and you leave the msg_id as the unique identifier, there is no way to detect New->Old, since the "old" system will send the response on the queue named by msg_id and the "new" system will be waiting on the queue named by "reply_q".

Note that there is no problem with queue deletion in this case.  The only confusion was in response to Andrea's suggestion that we use TopicConsumer for the replies and TopicConsumer in today's implementation does not use auto-delete, but of course we could change them to optionally auto-delete, but there were other reasons for not using TopicConsumer (whew).  The "old" and "new" system (this patch set) use auto-delete queues for the replies, meaning once the connection is closed, the queues are deleted.  It's just that with the "new" system (and amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue enabled), the connection is held open as long as the process exists.  With the "old" system, the connection is closed after the response is sent and since there is no consumer waiting on that queue, the message and the queue are simply deleted.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-24 19:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Ray, it might be more effective if we took this discussion out of the code review ;-)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-27 05:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

How about setting up a common wiki page with all of this information and communication (a tech doc u may say with Q/A with all of these comments?), its very useful to know all about this change and its affects (performance and old<->new among other reasons).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-01-28 18:40:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Do not merge

discussion moved to the ML: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-January/004972.html

Let's try to reach some consensus there"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-01-30 15:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-15 18:38:20.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue
AMQP RPC single per process response queue performance improvement
For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replace
the dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that
is created on teh first RPC call and used on all subsequent calls.
It provides backward compatibility on the callee side by recognizing
downlevel callers and on the caller side by addint a config option to
revert to the old dynamically created queue based upon the msg_id.

Change-Id: Idb09a71472866bd3950f58d4f7f45a3181eb40fc

For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replaces the
dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that is created

commit_message:
blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

For AMQP based RPC, specifically RabbitMQ and Qpid, this change replaces the
dynamically created RPC call reply queue with a single queue that is created
on the first RPC call and used on all subsequent calls. It provides backward
compatibility on the callee side by recognizing downlevel callers and on the
caller side by adding a config option to revert to the old dynamically
created queue based upon the msg_id.

Change-Id: Idb09a71472866bd3950f58d4f7f45a3181eb40fc

commit_message:
Fix old flags in cloudpipe doc

fixes bug 1128342

The bug reported noted that these were incorrectly using
the old style flag, and that the True was incorrectly
denoted. This patch makes the changes to fix it.

Change-Id: I1be8ed970d967e20a5d25e502ec5edec001b32a7

network traffic tuning parameters.

Blueprint: quota-instance-resource
DocImpact

commit_message:
remove intermediate libvirt downloaded images

* nova/virt/images.py (fetch_to_raw): When converting a downloaded
image to raw, ensure we delete the original download image.
I.E. the .part file.  The regression was introduced in 7c265343.
* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py (test_fetch_raw_image): A new test
for this function which wasn't tested previously.

Fixes bug: 1125068
Change-Id: Ie6f2cff1a554b8500fd66f0832566ae1b317be40

I keep coming back to this review hoping I'll figure out that this change is correct. First, why remove usage of UserRoleAssociation.id in LDAP?"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2013-02-01 20:08:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

When the first version of LDAP backend for Keystone was being implemented, this field was intensively used by Keystone core, so I added it to mimic behavior of SQL backend to the last detail.
Now these *Api classes are used only internally by backend and there's no need to pretend that the backend is relational, so no need to forge the id field of table holding many to many to many relation.
After all, this field even was absent in the UserRoleAssociation class (see my first patchset) and it broke only one method. So all these methods are just dead code, about 10% of this module."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-02-01 20:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-02-18 17:05:54.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround Migration issue with PostgreSQL

For unknown reason, SQLAlchemy-Migrate does not pass
the populate_default=True down to the ALTER TABLE statement.

Therefore, create the column in two steps, which
avoids the IntegrityError.

Change-Id: I30770d8b29ec442576a66fc07b2c78e2440fb328
'}, {'created': '2013-02-18 17:06:25.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround Migration issue with PostgreSQL

For unknown reason, SQLAlchemy-Migrate does not pass
the populate_default=True down to the ALTER TABLE statement.

Therefore, create the column in two steps, which
avoids the IntegrityError.

Fixes LP Bug 1068181

Change-Id: I30770d8b29ec442576a66fc07b2c78e2440fb328
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround Migration issue with PostgreSQL

For unknown reason, SQLAlchemy-Migrate does not pass
the populate_default=True down to the ALTER TABLE statement.

Therefore, create the column in two steps, which
avoids the IntegrityError.

Fixes LP Bug 1068181

Change-Id: I30770d8b29ec442576a66fc07b2c78e2440fb328

commit_message:
Fix undef function call in test_migrations for py26

unittest does not have this function until later. This uses the already
imported cinder.test.skip_unless to accomplish the same result without
outputted error.

Change-Id: Id20add5a0d41e5d8cf6f8bc6aa0e547e5e386dab

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

This patch implements routed service insertion as proposed at the Grizzly summit.

I recall long discussion with a part of the community being opposed to tying router_id to an advanced service, and service_type to a router.

On this note, I would like to point out that what is proposed here are API extensions which have not been wired in the respective base API classes (l3_db and lbaas db base class). Hence, it's a mechanism that, as it stands, has been developed for being plugin-specific.

IMHO this makes the patch acceptable even without community consensus.

Some comments inline."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

Cool job! Don't you fix l3-agent side in this patch?"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It looks small change, so IMO a separate bug report is sufficient.

For l3-agent part, I suppose this patch trying to implement this diagram.

http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum/ServiceInsertion?action=AttachFile&do=get&target=routed-si.png

IMO, in order to implement the diagram, l3-agent should be also need change. ( insert service by service type )
However it can be separate patch.  If so could you change the commit message to describe this.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-18 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add routed-service-insertion

Extend L3 router to add "service_type_id" attribute, and extend LB vip, pool,
and health_monitor to add "router_id" attribute.

Implements: API and DB model for blueprint routed-service-insertion
Change-Id: I12f053e0b0e6cf0813ea88dd568aae49b09b8215

commit_message:
Silence routes internal debug logging

Eliminates this spam while running keystone in debug:

  routes.middleware: DEBUG: Initialized with method overriding = True,
  and path info altering = True

Change-Id: I1ff1fb13b4bfea968a2ba8fe194141c98541c6b8

commit_message:
Correct the query filter specifications for certain urls

The query filter was incorrectly specified for the following urls:

GET /endpoints
GET /policies
GET /services

Fixes Bug #1128925

Change-Id: Ia1b102c7cf500b240ff2d063b61c8101f5012013

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-19 13:06:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

There are some structural things in here that I think need addressing. It would also be good to get some opinions from libvirt experts on this."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-21 10:02:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Given that this is quite a large amount of extra code, almost none of which is libvirt specific or directly tied to volume setup, I think it'd be desirable to pull most of it out into standalone module. eg perhaps nova/virt/linuxiscsi.py and then just call the relevent APIs from the Libvirt volume driver.

I think you need to do more in the test suite too. Your addition simply stubs out '_is_multipath_enabled' to False so none of the new functionality gets tested. You need to add a test with that set to True."}, {'account_id': 6652, 'date': '2013-01-27 15:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

[{'created': '2012-12-12 16:08:45.000000000', 'message': 'Enable multipath for libvirt iSCSI Volume Driver

Implements: blueprint libvirt-volume-multipath-iscsi

nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver now searches for
multipath, runs a scsi inquiry to the storage vendor (iSCSI portaa)
asking for more portals, logins to the discovered portals and uses a
multipath device (/dev/dm-X) instead of a singlepath device
(/dev/disk/by-path/ip-IP:PORT-iscsi-IQN-lun-X).

This improves IO speed and robustness, since if one iSCSI portal goes
down, there are still others to take care of IO.

commit_message:
Enable multipath for libvirt iSCSI Volume Driver

Implements: blueprint libvirt-volume-multipath-iscsi

nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver can now
make use of multipath (behavior defined by use_multipath flag)
runs a scsi inquiry to the storage vendor (iSCSI portal)
asking for more portals, logins to the discovered portals and uses a
multipath device (/dev/mapper/XX) instead of a singlepath device
(/dev/disk/by-path/ip-IP:PORT-iscsi-IQN-lun-X).

This improves IO speed and robustness, since if one iSCSI portal goes
down, there are still others to take care of IO.

Change-Id: I30489234b8329f576cf2cbb0ef390670dbee5b95

commit_message:
first-boot.d scripts log to a file:

Log first-boot.d script output to a file, to ease troubleshooting,
since the first-boot scripts are removed from the system after
running, even in case of failure.

Change-Id: I07d5c782dd918a804e054bf08efce89ed9442e0c

commit_message:
heat cli : Add --disable-rollback option to heat-cfn

When rollback is implemented it will default on, like aws
so this option allows stack rollback on create to be disabled

blueprint stack-rollback

Change-Id: I02fcaaa656219b1c65729cecdd473e0a5bd86036

at the end of the test, otherwise any cut/paste test
which uses the same stack name will always fail

commit_message:
heat tests : delete stacks from DB in parser tests

The tests which store a stack in the DB should delete it
at the end of the test, otherwise any cut/paste test
which uses the same stack name will always fail

Change-Id: Ib2e26480924bfe65a2f6fe8ae55076466394bcee

commit_message:
heat api : Handle DisableRollback parameter in cfn API

Previously we ignored DisableRollback for create/update,
pass it to the engine since the engine API now supports it

blueprint stack-rollback

Change-Id: I926d843a88449fa61b665bd1b47946724f6d2ce5

commit_message:
make engine api handle string or bool disable_rollback

Allow API's to pass string or bool format True/False flag
for the disable_rollback argument to the engine RPC API

Change-Id: I1886263ac2487c4cb36c8bd93fd1d09b04abe813

commit_message:
Update cinder-volume to enable multi volume support

* Added the service wrapper for multi binscripts
* Added a service_name to manager
* Added the configuration wrapper so the impls do not need
  to know if they are accessing config values from a option
  group or from the DEFAULT group
* Updated drivers to use the new configuration wrapper
* Added an example config set for multi backend
* Modified service to comply w/ common
* Added get_volume_stats to iscsi
* Added config for volume_backend_name

implements blueprint multi-volume-backends

Change-Id: Idb86ac5f1c06b9cd5061bef6a24f17727e9a58c1
